reviewText:
Basic InfosGameplay lengh: 3 - 20 Hours if you want to practice Speedrun, even more so if you want to raise to the top of the leaderbord ranking.
Required skill level: Medium to Very High - Experience can vary considering the creativity of the player
This game is for most audiences 12 years and up

About DeadCoreDeadCore is at its core (heh) is an interesting mix of well-known genres takes a step further. Think of it as Portal, but with an emphasis on movement physics rather than focusing on spartial problem solving. Its a rather unique mix that can be best discribed as a Jump and Run semi-FPS Speedrun game. Developer Team 5BitsGames tried hard to create a game that uses its game physics to create a very frantic game where shooting isn't the only important thing to do. The result is a unique mix of the two popular games Quake 2 and Portal.

And in my opinion it is much better than the Portal games alone.

GameplayWhile you still get to shoot flying robots and entities that are formed like Cubes, the gameplay is more about moving yourself in ways you wouldn't even think of in other games. More specifically the largest factor you have to consider before buying this game is the focus on movement and a calm and smooth aim rather then twitch reflexes. Furthermore memorizing each level, up of the entire game is essential for finding new ways to complete your quest in climbing the tower-themed world once again if you choose to play through it for another time.

Or in other terms, DeadCore is the perfect learn how to Speedrun game. From the beginning to end I never reached a part that was overly frustrating. The entire game really opens up once you see that this game wants you to Speedrun it instead of merely playing through it once.

As an example, the first level, which serves as a tutorial took me about 40 minutes to finish when I played through it for the first time. The second playthrough however, after a bit of foreplanning and with the small-but-useful skills you unlock during your first playthrough, took about 6 minutes to complete. A Leaderbord is included so you can compare the time it took to beat any level and even the entire game with your friends or everyone else if you choose to.

A Story does exist but the devs made sure that it is not rubbing you in the face. Rather then progressing with the story, you unlock bits and pieces explaining the setting by finding hidden Data Cubes through your journey, which can be accessed via a built-in journal. The Devs certainly knew that games like these focus on the gameplay. Its because of this focus on gameplay that the story itself becomes entirely a optional or even a entirely seperate factor, but it is still interesting to read through the bits and pieces you will find if you want to explore past the obvious routes. Theres also different upgrades to be found, which aren't needed if you want to beat the game, but should be gathered anyway if you try to speedrun the game. Otherwise you're up to a even greater challenge.

And that uniqueness the strongest point this game can offer to you. What may seem like a 5 hour long game that can be beaten in less then 20 minutes if you put creativity and foresight into it. Not with knowing about the route you went before, but finding a better way through the game that wasn't obvious to you during the first time. This is very similar to oldschool jump and run games, or games Speedrunners already have lots of experiences with. Or in different words, DeadCore is a modern game but with an very oldschool Heart and Soul. It takes the FPS genre, completly subverts the way people usually play these games and creates something that is almost unique.

Graphics and SoundWhen it comes to the general artistic direction, this game does look very solid indeed. Mint colors and the familiar 80's Neon look define its artstyle, which is often inspired by the movie Tron and the game Tron 2.0 yet this game achieved to still have a unique soul on its own. Premodeled shapes like cubes and slopes are placed as part of this games world. Each levels has a slightly unique style which also comes with the different lightning and a truely excellent skybox to create a fascinating atmosphere.

While the artstyle is the most positive factor here when it comes to rating the visuals, with its corny-cyberspacy look and feel, the problem here is the quality of the models used to build the levels. Sometimes I noticed that it does look a bit cheaper than I would've anticipate by looking at the screenshots from the steamstore page. Considering how open this world is this is not a major issue but its still worth mentioning that the game isn't always this good looking.

The sound, at least for me, seems to be the worst part about this game. Don't get me wrong, I love EDM as a whole but for the music in this game seemed rather generic. The minor varity of it is still a plus regardless. It also doesn't add anything important to the good atmosphere of this game. Furthermore the sound effects also don't stand out in any way but like the music, still get the job done.

So while the Soundtrack and the sound effects are the worst part of the game, they're still good enough to not consider they're out of place. Its just that the game is excelling due to the phenomenal freeform-speedrun gameplay and overall great art design that any other factor pales in comparision.

VerdictWhile not perfect, its obvious that 5BitsGames really cared about making this game just right" without overblowing it with features or making it too short. In terms of lengh
date: one playthrough is about 2 times as long as completing Portal 1. And like Portal 1 this game allows you to think outside the box without being too condecensing if you don't and as a result it becomes expecially rewarding to play it on your own device
recommended:
without any guide. Seeing that you finished one level in just under an hour in your first playthrough yet only mere minutes after the second one feels extremly good.

This game is a great example on the beauty of choice and out-of-the-box thinking right here. And this is something similar puzzle games like Portal 1 and even 2 could ever give to you.

Recommended food while playingMentos as a occasional snack or Peppermint Tea (I recommend Earl Grey
hoursPlayed: but tastes vary) if you prefer a drink instead"

reviewText:
The game pretty much exactly lives up to what you would expect from it. It's fast, it requires you to think quickly and act quickly but not to a level it get's really frustrating.

The artwork, well you either hate it or you love it. It's very simplistic with neon like effects at the same textures over and over again. But who gives 2 ♥♥♥♥♥ about that anyway, the game is beautiful in many aspects. The music fits too, which ingame is much more ambient than the trailer(really didn't like the music there so that's a good thing too(♥♥♥♥ dnb)).

Few things you're not going to find in this game:
->A good storyline. There is one, and it consists of logs to clear up your lost memory(doesn't get more original than that hur dur). They aren't awfully well written either. I just looked at them and was like 'mmwyeah lets ignore those' lol

->Puzzles that require more than 2 braincells. It's just not a thinking game. Not to be confused with Portal, which has a somewhat similar style

->Enemies that are actually a treat to you. lol the enemies are probably the worst thing so far. They're just ''kamikaze cubes''(it's worse than it sounds though) and they're extremely predictably placed over the map. They've got a different color than regular cubes so you can just pick them off immediately. Somewhat saddening, but I didn't really need enemies in this game anyway.

Later on there're some more advanced enemies which I won't spoil. But they aren't really anything either, they're all pretty uninteresting by design(to me at least)

What you can expect however is:
->Some neat-o floating sky platform-world which makes as much sense as the idiot who came up with the idea of giving this game a '' storyline ''

->Smooth gameplay, apart from some minor pointers like getting stuck on the edge of some cubes here and there

->Clever level design

->The level design actually rewards you if you decide to go for an alternative route, which there're suprisingly many of.

->Some damn sweet and fitting sounds. Including the music

I mean for 40 euros this game might've been really dubious in more than 1 way. But for 10 euro, ah hell naw boii. You better get this, it's great.

reviewText:
Nowadays, video gaming is a hobby shared by almost everybody in the whole damn world. There are hardcore players, who’ll spend hours upon hours playing the same game because they need to be the best. There are the story players, who can lose entire weekends to titles like the Mass Effect series, bonding with those on the journey and sharing their ups and downs. There are more casual players, who enjoy nothing more than a few levels of Angry Birds on the commute to work. And then there are the type of masochistic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who like platformers like Super Meat Boy, I Wanna Be The Guy, and a recent addition to the list Deadcore.
Let me take a step back and explain. Deadcore is a new platformer produced by Namco Bandai and developed by 5 Bits Games. It combines fast paced platforming elements with twitch-gameplay FPS elements. This creates an experience that’ll keep you living in the moment, one eye on the obstacles you’re trying to navigate and the other looking ahead, planning the path you’ll be taking. It’s the type of game that requires lightning fast reflexes and the patience to put into practice that age old motto; If at first you don’t succeed, try and try again.
Deadcore throws you straight into the action with little fanfare or fluff. In fact, the story isn’t revealed to you at all; it’s up to you to go and find it.  Hidden throughout the levels are various collectables, including songs from the games soundtracks and documents that piece together a story. A story of a man desperate to escape from…um, someone… Look, I’ll level with you, I didn’t find many of them, and the ones I did find were all spread apart from each other so they didn’t really form a cohesive plot.
I found that intriguing, though. It gave me a genuine desire to go back and see what I’d missed, not many games do. While some of them are hidden in plain sight, maybe around a corner you could quite easily spot. Many require you to go the extra mile, finding new routes and thinking about the game in new ways to experience all it has to offer.
I’d love to be able to label this as a free running platform game, but it just doesn’t tick the free running box for me. If it combined the elements of gameplay it already has, with aspects of Mirror’s Edge, I don’t think I’d be able to contain my excitement. The gameplay it has doesn’t lack excitement though. The controls are tight enough to feel like you’re in charge at all times. Whenever you throw yourself into a laser wall or off the tower you’re trying to climb, you know it was entirely your fault.
Deadcore’s level design was exhilarating to me, incredibly clever and well thought out. Many sections of each level have multiple paths. As one of the in-game logs states; “There are several paths to choose from, but everyone’ll tell you the same thing; only the quickest one counts”. It’s a matter of trial and error to find which one is indeed the fastest, but I can foresee the speed running community having a ball with this game.
The shooter element in Deadcore is pretty interesting, cause there aren’t many enemies in the traditional sense. While you won’t be gunning down hordes of aliens, bugs or soldiers, that trigger finger will still be kept busy. The primary use for your gun is to activate and deactivate certain areas in the environment. There are boosters that propel you forcefully in their pointed direction, and you might need to turn those off mid-jump to save yourself from being blasted to your doom. There are blocks that come to life and chase you, exploding when they catch up and almost certainly knocking you from your platform.
The game, like most modern platformers of it’s type, handles death very well. When you die, you respawn almost instantly, and there’s a button you can press that forces you to reappear at the last checkpoint immediately. No frustrating waiting times or irritating loading screens with ‘helpful’ tips. You die, you get back up, you move forward again. Rinse and repeat. The checkpoints are placed far enough apart to prove challenging, but not far enough to cause any anger when you fail.
Finally, one of my favourite aspects of Deadcore is the draw distance on the tower. At any point, you can turn and look down and see the levels you’ve already made your way through, the obstacles you’ve cleared. Looking up shows just how far you’ve got left to go, and what you’ve still to face. The first time I noticed, it left me dizzy and slightly nauseated. It was breathtaking.
If you’ve got the patience to keep at it, Deadcore is an amazing new take on a tried and tested formula. The gameplay elements it combines run seamlessly into each other, with nearly flawless level design. It offers immense replayability for the Speed Runner crowd, and a challenging, rewarding experience for everybody who plays it. This is definitely one to add to your collection.

reviewText:
People keep making comparisons to Portal, so I'll just say this:

This is not Portal.  This is not Portal.  This is not Portal.

The entire point of the Portal series was to make games that are both challenging AND accessible to the widest possible audience.  Valve tuned the levels specifically to get as many people to drop their hard earned cash as possible.

You can tell this is the case, because Portal 2 is not Portal, Only Way Harder.  Even the first game pulled its punches in how far it went with the puzzles -- they wanted players to fully understand the mechanics without being overwhelmed by them.

DeadCore, on the other hand, is a game made for a very specific, very small audience: FPS speedrunners.  It is not made for anybody else.  The entire point of the game is for people who are already crazy skilled to show off how crazy skilled they are, and for everybody else to watch.

Note I said watch"
date: not "play".  If you are not already someone who speedruns games
recommended: this one brick walls its difficulty starting around level 2.\n\nIt requires very precise movements
hoursPlayed: and demands twitch reflexes to pass the puzzles.  It uses infinite respawns as an excuse to ambush the player with traps that cannot be avoided on the first playthrough.  It makes the player (and the player's hitbox) completely invisible -- you don't even have the visual feedback of casting a shadow

reviewText:
Let me start this off by saying I am in love with this game. The controls are incredibly tight and responsive, the story mode is paced very well with the diffuculty ramping up but allowing you to go back through with new techniques that will allow you to explore more areas and quicker on subsequent playthroughs.

With that said there is a slight problem with the speedrunning, I am on top of the leaderboards on a lot of the zones because there is a technique that I'm sure isnt intended that allows you to pretty much circumvent how the game was meant to be played.

I believe this needs to be fixed if the leaderboards are supposed to be a real competition.

Pros:
Tight controls
Nice pacing in difficulty
Incredible replay value
Timed speedruns
Multiple paths
Visually impressive

Cons:
Broken technique allowing gamebreaking movement
Somewhat short
Some keys such as shift arent bindable

Things I hope are added into the game that I believe would make this game my favorite of all time:
Replay function to see other's runs
Fix the broken technique that allows for unintended movement
Community level creator
More content! (Expansions/DLC/Patches)

I rate this game a 9/10

reviewText:
Fast, precise, with a well balanced learning curve. The Leveldesign makes the movements exhilarating. You will rejoice when clearing several sections without a stop.

DeadCore fuses the needforspeed pleasure of Trackmania, the precision and nonstop pace of golden FastFPSs, and the instinctive and quicktolearn leveldesign of Portal2.
The audio/Musical layer of minimalist electro is highly dynamic : it gives the beat to your bloodcells and encourages you to keep at it when you're struggling on a section.

On top of that, the technical work is flawless : it gives high framerates, a wide and adjustable FoV, and amazing visuals !

Also, you can turn the game into a race and battle on the leaderboards.

***********************
Français :
Rapide, précis, courbe d'apprentissage bien dosée ! Le leveldesign rend les mouvements jouissifs. Et on jubile quand on arrive à enchainer les sections sans s'arrêter.

DeadCore combine les effets grisants de trackmania Stadium, la vitesse de mouvements ainsi que la précision des fastFPS, le level design instinctif et instructif de Portal.
Et une couche audio/musicale électro minimaliste est très interactive : elle donne le rythme et encourage à insister quand on bute sur une section.

Et en plus la réalisation technique est sans faute et visuellement c'est beau et impressionant ! FOV Modifiable !

Si en plus vous aimez un minimum les challenge, tous les niveaux sont chronométrés et vous pourrez vous mesurer aux chronos de tous les autres joueurs.

reviewText:
Well designed all around, but horribly, horribly frustrating.
I enjoyed the first few levels, but doing the same challenge 40 times because it takes millimeter-precission to complete is just not something I want to spend my time on.
The game has some great potential, and shines at the moments where it forces you to act fast and improvise, but a small number of insanely hard gauntlets stops the flow of the excellent platforming dead in its tracks.
Would recommend, but you need to understand what you´re buying, and like a serious challenge. Certainly not a game for everyone. Not for me, for instance.

reviewText:
Deadcore is a very unique game, but if i had to compare it to something, it would most likely be Portal franchise.

In essence, it is a very, very difficult and demanding first-person platformer based on combinations of few monumental platforming skills - double jump and dash. You also use a weapon, but game involves very little combat, as your enemies are just mechanical traps which the weapon disables for a brief moment. Game also features some mind-bending gravity shifting & jump-pad mechanics, which only add to the overall flavor of super tough experience.

You have to keep in mind - this game was designed with speed-running in mind. Given, i beat the game in 8 hours and my actual run time not taking into account all trial-and-error was 4:11 hours, you can see how much repetition can the game require from someone with not that decent hand-eye coordination. However, with perserverance you can definitely beat it and the pay-off, while confusing, in the end is worth it. Despite all the frustration, i do see it as a great, unique gaming experience and i do recommend it you try it.

+ Graphics - very, very cool and in places (especially epilogue level) breathtaking.
+ Level design - though some checkpoints are too scarcely placed it is manageable.
+ Sound design - very good, all actions you perform give adequate feedback and add to the mysterious sci-fi atmosphere.
+ Performance - first i thought it wasn't that great, but it was, turns out my integrated and dedicated GPUs were fighting about this game. However there are few notable locations in game where the overwhelming amount of enemy-trap thingies and visual filters murder the fps. That does not hinder game progress however.
+- Story - depends on how you look at it, there are logs scattered across the levels that tell the lore, but i did not find the story to be a significant part of the game. I will, however, look up all the possible endings cause i don't believe i can achieve them myself.
- Music - i personally didn't like that drum & bass here at all and found it a little unfitting, but perhaps my slow pace had something to do with that.

Overall score - 9/10. A great purchase, definitely not only on sale price. For a completionist there's more than enough collectible hunting and time trials.

reviewText: Deadcore feels to me like it combines some of the best aspects of the first-person gameplay from Valve's Portal titles while at the same time incorporating the acrophobia-inducing platforming featured in Coilworks' Cloudbuilt. In the short period of time that I've spent playing the game, I have to say that it's as fun as it is beautiful. If ever I wanted to play a game using the Oculus Rift, this would be it.

reviewText:
Don't let the speedrunning nature of the game discourage you, it can still be enjoyed even by old people with slower reflexes. Some patience and practice can give a very rewarding feeling everytime you hit the next checkpoint.

The game at it's core is an obstacle course, where the main goal is travelling from point A to B through lethal traps and pitfalls.
Early on the game teaches you that you can use and exploit any object in the physics-defying architecture around you, sometimes even using a trap itself to propel yourself forward. This aspect of Deadcore adds a puzzle element to the whole experience, so it's not just a twitch-based runner. Combining the puzzle aspect with the branching paths in each level the game lets you carve your own trail opting for a safer or a faster route. Even though there are no walls, no ceiling or even a floor most of the times, you can still be creative in how you progress through the labyrinthine levels, since there are multiple ways to crosss each obstacle. The player can be slow and methodical at some parts figuring out the way for himself or use timing and platforming skills at others. At first you will only be able to traverse a basic path as the developer intended, but the more tools and power-ups you unlock, the more the game itself opens up to you.

Deadcore also rewards exploration and pushes the player to search for 3 different types of collectibles. First type unlocks more bits of the story helping you to understand your environment and it's purpose. Second type unlocks more music tracks, ranging from ambient to D'n'B and jungle beats. The third type opens up completely new paths in the levels, adding even more complexity and replayability.

The main and only downside that comes to mind is the game's lengh. Takes about 10 hours for a slow casual player like myself to make 2 full cycles of the game and unlock the secret" ending. After that point
date: any replayability is based on speedrunning and ranking up in the player lists
recommended: or achievement hunting if that's your thing (all of achievements easily feasible).\n\nIn summary: Deadcore is a butt-clenching adrenaline fix with a unique gameplay experience
hoursPlayed: part puzzler part speed runner."

reviewText:
The graphics and sound is really cool in this game, but what makes it really a good game is, that it doesn't hold your hand or shoves you along, just so that you feel good. If you beat this game, it is because of your own skill, not because the developers put in a hundred safety lines just to pull you along. You have to be very precise in your jumping and shooting otherwise you will fail. If you fail, you must try harder. As simple as that.

Playing DeadCore reminds me a lot of the old times playing Quake 3 or getting all the secrets in Painkiller, just without enemies. A definite recommendation to all who like FPS style games with fast paced graphics. I'm really glad that I found this game by accident during a sale because I haven't heard about it before.

10/10

reviewText:
If you are a platforming genius DeadCore will be your ultimate challenge as the difficulty is raking the highest tops. It might even be so hard that certain players will simply drop off, but if you are not afraid of insanely complicated puzzles you have to give this a try.

A lot of skill, fast reflexes and quick maneuvering are keys to solve the riddle throughout its 5 levels. If it just had a few more checkpoints so it wasn't unbearably punishing then it would have been a 9 or 10, but I feel that it solidly earns a well deserved 8/10.

You get a few different abilities to play with (double jump

I was just walking in a straight line?" At other times you will find yourself playing for 2-3 minutes going through an insane adrenaline rush inducing sequence that's really hard (and can let you die a couple of times) and then you respawn back at the beginnig. Some better ordering of the checkpoints might've helped here.


The VerdictThe main problem with most people playing the game is probably that they think you can play it like a Portal game. What DeadCore actually is is a side-scrolling jump and run that is played from a first-person perspective. For about 50% of the game I didn't know that myself and was at times ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off about how some sequences are laid out. But in the end I understood that it's not about puzzles and thinking
column28: it's very often just about running into something and figuring out the rhythm. Then you will get adrenaline rushing in your blood and after a longer sequence you land on a checkpoint
column30: look at what you just crossed and think "Wow
column32: exactly?"\n\nThose are a lot of moments where the game shines and is super fun. At the other hand some sequences are so hard to manage or way too long that it makes you freak out and punch something Borderlands-Brick-style. But those are not most moments. It's a game with a high sense of urgency that is very real once you find a bunch of timers running inside your head on when to jump next. It's fast and keeps up a nice pace with only few moments to catch a breath. Oddly enough I found it very relaxing to play after work because of all those immense jumps
column33: combined with the your abilities which give you a real nice sense of free movement in three dimensions.\n\nAll in all
column34: if you're not sure about the whole rage-quitting thing wait for an 50% off or more offer but if you're into annoying jump'n'runs /and/ Portal
column35: go for it and buy it."

reviewText:
I cannot reccommend this game enough, don't let this slip under your radar!

It's punishingly difficult at times, with absoltuely zero hand-holding or easing-into-difficulty, but it's also amazingly engaging and fun: you never feel overwhelmed, or as if things are just pointlessly/needlessly difficult and rage inducing. Instead the controls are tight, the game runs super well, all the challenges, while often tough have that magic element of fun that makes you grin ear-to-ear, flex your hands again and dive right back in to see if you can *just get that timing right*, or maybe even try a new path or tactic.

The music is also great-great by itself, and the perfect complement to the artstyle of the game.
The story, super mysterious (so far) is intriguing and engaging.

Downsides: My hands hurt
I'm going to be tired tomorrow due to staying up all night playing this.
[\list]

10/10 would recommend.

reviewText:
Probably one of my top five games released in 2014. It's a shame practically nobody knows about it, it's super fun. So fun that I actually went out of my way to review it because I feel like it deserves more attention.

To sum up the game, I would say it is a speedrunning fast paced game based around mobility. If you played Dishonored and liked the blink mechanic, you'll love this.

The aesthetics, graphics, atmosphere, and soundtrack are all fantastic. The gameplay is super fast paced, but the overall pacing of the game is good. It introduces new mechanics at a good pace and doesn't overload you with information. Then, it tests you on it all.

There's a great feeling when you manage to pull off something crazy such as pulling off a crazy stunt that you think that the developers probably didn't realize you could do. But the thing is, the developers did know probably. The map design is phenomenal. Because the game takes entirely in the sky, every single thing placed is deliberate and every jump calculated. So, when you pull off that crazy jump, you know at the back of your mind that you beat the developer's challenge that you didn't even know they were challenging you to.

Deadcore is one of the few games that I've actually wanted to go back and replay. Because you unlock new mechanics and powerups, going back and replaying levels to see new areas that you can reach and collecting sparks" (which reveal new parts of the level) is super satisfying. Beating a level five times faster than you did originally is a great experience that really shows off how much you've progressed
date: through mastering mechanics and unlocking the new ones.\n\nAlso

reviewText:
Summary:Deadcore was a simple yet well crafted platforming game that required high precision and skill to complete. The game feels very polished and well rounded. The story is pretty bare, which is fine because that isn't the game's main focus at all. The main goal is to get to the top of the tower using coordination, puzzle solving, and some minor FPS elements to disable enemies or traps. The campaign doesn't take too long, however speedrunning the levels can get very addicting. This game uses tight controls and good level design (most of the time) to provide an enjoyable experience to the player, casual or hardcore.

Pros:
Good graphics and world design to emmerse the player in the game. While it's nothing phenominal, it's definitely above average.
The puzzles and level design provide for entertaining gameplay and feel very fluid despite being very challenging at times.
Tight controls make the platforming feel fair and fun to play.
Speedrunning modes to put your skills to the test. It compares you on the global leaderboard and on your friendslist leaderboard.
The extra pickups are very well hidden and are a great addition for completionists.
Neutral:
The music is decent and adds to the atmosphere of the game. While it isn't the best soundtrack I've ever heard, it definitely fits the genre and helps keep a steady rhythm while you're playing.
Cons:
The enemy placement can be a bit frustrating in the final few levels.
Overall:8.2/10

reviewText:
DeadCore pulls absolutely no punches in being exactly what it wants to be.

A first person, speedrunning focused sci-fi platformer, it's unabashedly everything it proclaims itself to be and doesn't give a damn if you can keep up with the absurdly high performance requirements placed upon the player. So I guess it's fair to say it accomplished its goals, that it became the game it was designed to be, but for all it's gorgeous particle effects and impress sense of speed it's so obsessed with being this monumental hurdle to overcome that it neglects to ever give you a reason to want to.

There's no difficultly curve in DeadCore, just you and a brick wall of unintuitive level designs, agonizingly spaced out checkpoints, stiff controls, and everything that's ever been a problem with first-person platformers. Its perspective is likely it's largest oversight, as it makes it extremely hard to accurately jump onto minuscule platforms when you can't see where you're landing, and having to constantly look down to counteract this obscures the omnipresent series of instant death obstacles you have to simultaneously dodge.

I never felt in control playing DeadCore. Every jump was a gamble, a roll of the dice deciding whether I miraculously made it through or would be sent back usually not knowing why I died, or feeling like I was being punished for things I had no chance of avoiding. It's overwhelming and constantly punishing, to the point the idea that I would return to try and better my times was almost laughably ridiculous.

For as constantly as it reminds and urges you to make your own path, progression in DeadCore is unrelentingly strict. Any diverging paths usually boiled down to an occasional fork in the road or making an impossible jump that might have saved me a few seconds, but I was always trapped in this impenetrable obstacle course. Level designs are obtuse and at times forced me to do things that felt like I was breaking the game because there was no other discernible way through. The purity of its mechanics is then lost as I unsuccessfully tried to perform the tasks set before me as the game continued to tell me I was either doing it wrong, or not doing it well enough.

When I finally made it to the top of the tower I'd been ascending throughout the game, my sigh wasn't one of satisfaction that I'd finally managed to overcome the seemingly impossible obstacles that stood in my way, but one of relief that I'd never have to go through them again. I have no doubts that there are people DeadCore will simply click with, who would tell me I'm just bad at it and if I would only give it more of a chance I'd begin to enjoy it. Be that as it may, completing DeadCore just once was such an unbelievably stressful and frustrating experience that I can't imagine willingly taking on that task again, and would feel sick with myself if I recommended anyone else do so anyway.

You can read more of my reviews on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
I just 100%'d the game (steam achievements) so I'm going to try and write a review. Yay!

DeadCore is a fantastic FPS parkour puzzle speedrunner game. The objective is to reach the top of a mysterious tower by running, jumping, and using your trusty Switch Gun to activate and/or deactivate switches, enemies, moving walls, and gravity fields, while trying not to get disintegrated by lasers or fall to your death (which is by lasers most of the time anyway because a floor of lasers follows you upwards whenever you reach a new checkpoint). Most of the enemies don't actually kill you, but the turrets and troopers launch you away (often into lasers) and the mosquitoes slow you down (so you can be killed by moving lasers).

The whole game can be speedrun in less than an hour, but it takes several hours to finish the first time, familiarise yourself with the levels, learn some speedrun strats, and find the hidden Sparks to unlock the game's true ending.

+ The controls are simple and responsive: WASD to move, E to boost, M1 to shoot, M2 to aim (personally didn't find much point in aiming), and M3 to blast.
+ The feeling of speed is very nicely communicated (did I describe that right?)
+ The graphics are very nice and sleek-looking, even on very low (;_; my computer)
+ The levels are well designed, with some tough challenges, often with multiple paths, and encourage a bit of exploration to find the collectables
+ Speedrun mode! Leaderboards! Beat the devs!
+ Beating the dev times, completing a paticularly difficult section of a level, finding short cuts, finding hidden collectables, and just being launched high into the air and boosting around, gives a lot of satisfaction.
+/- The difficulty ramps up quite a bit, and in the later levels you will die many times to the challenges. This is a personal thing, I enjoyed the difficulty but some people won't.
- Story doesn't really make sense. Or maybe I'm too literal-minded.
- You have no body and it's a bit hard to know what your hitbox is going to do

Overall a great game, I highly recommend it to fans of first person parkour or speedrun games, and people who like a challenge.

reviewText:
If you're a platforming fan, you owe it to yourself to play DeadCore.

It's a somewhat challenging FPS-platformer in the vein of Portal. Movement is very smooth and jumping has a fair bit of airhang to it to help you know your bearing, you always feel in control and the only jarring thing I can point to is some mild annoyances with narrowing down your hitbox at first.

The platforming challenges are imaginative and diverse and the level design is solid: levels have a very dynamic and animate feeling to them, where you in contrast feel like a manipulator, dissecting and disrupting the world around you. DeadCore is also quite branched, both in terms of official alternate routes as well as hidden shortcuts that can be found through exploiting dashes and rocketjumping.

One thing that bears mentioning though is that the levels lean heavily towards the GMOD near the end, where you activate gravity panels and flip in a variety of angles to get to otherwise unreachable locations, if motion sickness is an issue to you or you have a general apathy towards disorientation in platformers, then it's a valid concern and something that may put you off the game.

Otherwise, intriguing atmosphere, smooth controls and high quality level design, definitely recommended.

reviewText:
This first-person platformer is perfectly executed, smooth as hell and gorgeous to boot. The levels are colossal, even putting DarkSouls to shame, but within a short period you'll be dashing and bouncing your way around making short work of sections that at first proved challenging.

One of the best things about Deadcore is something it doesn't do... It doesn't restrict you. If you want to, and have the skills to jump around a puzzle or laser grid instead of through it, that's fine. If you fancy going off-piste and climbing up that decorative curved roof to reach the next area early: Be our guest!

I'd go into details about the abilities and upgrades and stuff, but suffice to say it's a nice simple system that gives good replay value without feeling cheap (it's even worked into the lore).

There's story here but it's Braid-esque, take it or leave it. It's not bad, just not really that important. Gameplay is what makes Deadcore shine.

Considering the dev team can be counted on one hand, this is a masterpiece.[8.7]

reviewText:
Amazing 3D platformer. Traverse the beautiful world using double jump and horizontal dash. Toggle objects in the world with your gun. Avoid various obstacles and annoying enemies.

The game is difficult but not too difficult. Has frequent checkpoints.

It takes ~4 hours for the first playthrough to just reach the finish. But that's far from everything the game has to offer.

The exploration is really enjoyable. Each level is huge, and when you play them for the 2nd time you are able to find whole new branches with higher difficulty. There are also collectibles that are a challenge to hunt down.

And of course, there is the whole speedrun mode, for those who are into this.

Includes a lot of nice soundtrack.

★★★★★★★★★☆

reviewText:
Mildly challenging and very fun to play.

On the art: the graphics seem impressive on the surface, but if you look closely (as others have said) there's a high amount of texture reuse. The clouds are also 2D projections which follow the player's gaze. But none of this actually affects gameplay, besides ruining immersion a bit. I think the sound design is awesome, though, and overall I think this game takes many inspirations from Portal 2's style. (edit: I feel as if later in the game, the developers stopped striving for a 'wow effect', which is okay, I guess. There's only so much 'newness' to go around. I noticed when I went back to the first level from the third.)

On the gameplay: I like it. Platformers have classically been the prerogative of 2D or 2.5D. It's very nice to see a 3D platformer, and intriguing to see how unconventional and innovative platformer mechanics have been shown in this game. This game is an obstacle course and only 5 maps\lvls short.

reviewText:
Wow, great game!  While the early puzzles are fairly easy, the difficulty gradually ramps up and within a few levels a lot of the game elements begin to combine into puzzles that are genuinly difficult to consistently pass.  'Consistently' being the operative word, as you die a LOT (or at least I did)  and so therefore have a lot of chances to perfect your technique.  Happily though the respawn points are liberally placed and there's no limit to your number of tries, so no worries.

Graphics looks great on a high end-machine with 4K monitor and is very smooth.  Love looking down at all of the levels that you've done and up at the one's you're still to do.  Thought the music is pretty good, although some of the sound effects get a bit repetative after you've heard them for the hundredth time.

Really fun and inventive and, in my oppinion, by far the best puzzle game since the portal series and better in many ways.  Great work.

reviewText:
Hard one to review.

Ultimately I would only recommend this game to someone in love with the first person jump puzzle genre.

It's fiendishly hard, the sound effects are good, and it has some nice graphical aesthetics.

On my macbook pro I had to wind down the graphics options to minimal to get a steady framerate (required to not die) and even then I get occasional judder.

The big problem is what many other reviewers state...  The controls are a bit stiff, and it doesn't ever feel like I'm getting better at it.  Every time I go for one of the tiny platforms I feel like there's a really good chance I'll miss it and plumet to my instant death.

If you're really into first person trick jumping then maybe you'll like it, however the majority of gamers won't enjoy this game

reviewText:
This game is a platforming FPS game. It does share a similarity with Portal but the genre they're both in is as far as the similarities go. DeadCore is vastly different from Portal. Rather than use...well...portals to get around and solve puzzles, you jump around, run, dash, and shoot switches to progress.

This is a very difficult game. It requires a lot of precise movement to get through the various hazards placed throughout the 5 levels. There's also the added challenge of it being in first-person, which means you can't entirely see your surroundings, but that's not a huge issue. DeadCore is also a fairly fast paced platformer, you don't have much time to react to hazards and other obstacles which gives even more challenge.

There's also various collectables hidden throughout the game. Music, hidden pathways, upgrades, and even lore. The lore isn't really anything special, but hey, it's there so might as well look at it once.

The only real problem I have is, because it's in first person, you don't have a good idea of what your hitbox is. This is a problem because later parts of the game require you to go through very narrow pathways, and since you can't see what your hitbox is, expect a lot of deaths. You also can't see any incoming hazards easily, though it's less of an issue.

DeadCore is a good game. It's short, but because of how the game works, there's some nice replayability and some potential for some cool speedrunning tactics. I give it an 8/10
voteText: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Good
* Looks great, impressive that this was made with Unity.
* Gameplay has multiple mechanics rather than just jumping.
* Lots of checkpoints, never far from where you die.
* Small dev team (5 people) are highly active on the game forum.
* Fairly priced.

Bad
* No antialiasing option ingame and forcing MSAA through drivers doesn't do anything. Since the aesthetic is almost all straight lines, jaggies are quite noticeable.
* Really obvious microstutter regardless of frame rate. Even at a constant 120 fps, it looks like 40 fps. Others have mentioned this in the forum - devs are looking into it.
* Some of the gameplay mechanics. For example, many times you will have to 'dash' between horizontal laser beams. Since it's first person and you can't see your character model, there's a lot of guessing at first to know whether your character's hitbox will hit the lasers or not. The gravity shifting mechanic in the second half of the game can also be very disorienting as it constantly shifts your camera automatically. Not a fan of the perspective changes in a fast-paced first person game.

reviewText:
Feels like CS surfing/bhopping with enviromental manipulation.

I surf a lot, mainly in csgo. To be a better surfer, a base level understanding of map layout and player movement is essential to finishing with decent times. This same challenge applies to deadcore.

I see a lot of comparisons to portal here in the reviews.
Specific sounds are played at different times (like when you launch off of an air lift) similar to Portal 2, but use of a portal gun (thinking with portals) has no comparison in deadcore, to me.
Deadcore is about movement, memorization and effectiveness. not
puzzle solving, exploration, and story.

Deadcore allows for the player to decide their path based on their implementation of the dash, jump, and rocket jump. The gun is used to open doors, stun enemies, and rocket jump (for advanced players). I've been rewarded by this game's challenge, and I have enjoyed the upgradability and stortytelling from finding collectables.

reviewText:
DeadCore is a really satisfying platforming FPS with a healthy dose of on-the-fly thinking and breathtaking graphics. The best part is that the game actually does look and play as great as the trailers imply.

What's even more impressive that this was made by a team of 5 people rather than being a high-budget AAA title with a massive team working on it. As you can see from the screenshots, the graphics are stunning, and the sound and music both accompany the game's atmosphere and theme exceptionally well. Not only is there a story mode where you venture to the peak of the massive tower, but there are several hidden items to find that unlock things like bits of the backstory and more music to listen to. There's even a speedrun mode for the highscore chasers.

I was surprised by the game's price, too; for $11, it's a pretty great purchase.

reviewText:
DeadCore has what's probably my ideal scenario for a game: You fall through the sky and land near the bottom of an impossibly high, architecturally abstract tower, built out of moving and floating pieces, patrolled by mechanical sentries. You have powerful movement options and find tools to make them even more powerful. As you progress, you see flashes of words associated with your immediate task, seemingly the thoughts and warnings of people who have been here before you. Climb to the top.

This is platforming in its purest form - dash, double jump, avoid death fields, boost high up, create your own shortcuts, shoot down enemy sentries, and keep climbing. The movement mechanics are so robust they have a visual artistry to them. The music is a combination of ambient soundscape and thumping electronica.

What little context exists is abstract and light. You find logs with flavor text but they're all pretty interchangeable. DeadCore is just about climbing the tower and (optionally) collecting the sparks that activate something at the top. It's incredibly fun.

Note on speedrun mode: The game has been patched a few times to remove major climbing/clipping exploits, but several still remain. There are obscure ways to boost yourself from the bottom of a level to the top. Unless it gets patched again (which seems unlikely), don't sweat the leaderboards too much and just play it the way you want to.

reviewText:
DEADCORE REVIEW- COVERING THE GAME AS A WHOLE! (Tried to make this as complete as I could- sorry it's long).
After watching the trailers, I thought this looked like a pretty fun game... and boy did it deliver! When I dived into it, I was more than just in awe! Deadcore is definately on my list of top games in 2014! I highly recommend Deadcore to anyone who wants a challenge, or likes speed runs, fps puzzle, or platformers in general.

The gameplay is fast paced, extremely satisfying and the mechanics are brilliant. The general idea of the switch gun is simply genius, and adds a unique element to the game. The other abilities are also great- dash, g-mod and blast are unlocked further in and add more challenges and allow you to go back and explore previously unaccessible areas. Please note that the BLAST EXPLOIT HAS BEEN FIXED- so you can't use blast to climp up easily. You will have to play the legit way like I did! :p

The world itself is dangerous, mysterious and intriguing. It is quite an adventure through this game and it keeps you interested and curious. There are lots of different secrets to unlock- new pathways, and hidden collectibles- logs, music tracks, sparks, and more powerups- like ammo or dash boosts. The logs you find develop a small, story like explination that really adds to the feel of the game. Sparks unlock areas that are a faster route, but also more challenging. Exploring the world is unexpectedly fun- by that I mean that a first glance at the game would not suggest there is the exploration element. The soundtrack is perfect for the game- with a mix of fast paced, awesome tracks. The design is kinda Tron like, and suites the game perfectly.

It has a very good learning curve and a very high skill cap. You gain more abilities, experience and knowledge the further you get. Sometimes, you will get stuck on a particular part and it will be EXTREMELY RAGE INDUCING. My advice is to NOT RUSH and to analyse the challenge so you know where you're going wrong. Timing can be a very key factor to success. The enemies are cool but can be very frustrating, especially as I found the hit boxes on them are very small- one issue I had was that sometimes you hit the cubes and they don't deactivate- the shot needs to be too central for my liking. Wasps can be infuriating, and turrets are considerably rapid fire. The bosses" are pretty awesome. Another issue I had was that you don't get a good feel of your size- meaning lazers can often hit you when you think you're clear. Some of the lazers I thought were a little too punishing- particularly ones that rotate. Also
date: I hate the laser tunnels you have to dash through. Sometimes the game offers little to no room for error- and the slightest wrong move can kill you.\nThis adds to the overall challenge though
recommended: and when you do get past that one bit you were stuck on
hoursPlayed: it is SO REWARDING! Each level gives new challenges that increase your skill. I myself am not very accurate and my reflexes aren't too sharp

reviewText:
Sci-fi first-person puzzle-platformer. Very ethereal, gorgeous, metallic setting, with cool music to back up the pacing. Controls fairly tightly, but can be very frustrating if your reflexes are not up to par. Frequent respawns, and a decent amount of trial-and-error. If you were looking for another Portal, this isn't it. If you were looking for another Antichamber, this isn't that either.

There's a moderately interesting story hidden in the collectible logs (among the other collectibles), but you likely will miss big pieces if you don't collect all the logs.

It's pretty dang short and does have some replay value for those interested in collectibles and speedrunning... I got it on sale for $4 and felt that it was well worth it.

I would give it a 7/10, but it's an 8/10 in my book because I think I got a lot more satisfaction out of it than I expected for my purchase. If you're not a fan of first-person platforming, you should probably steer clear to save yourself frustration... It can get ragequit-inducing at times.

reviewText:
Do not be afraid of heights !

A really hardcore platformer-FPS, I've done 4 or 5 levels so far and some segments are really hard for my heart (he took me almost one hour to finish the last level I played last night...), I might have an heart attack before finishing the game. Some timing and placements are closed to frame/pixel perfect but if you're not affraid to die and retry go for it.

It seems to have a decent lifetime with multiple forks on each level and some segments are unlockable with mechanics acquired in next levels.

Plus everything is already in place to speedrun for the bravest. :-)

Brutal. Unforgiving. Amazing.

The ultimate in first person platforming, DeadCore offers refreshing game that will push your dexterity to the limits. While there will still remain some luck elements (especially towards the end of the game) beating it is incredibly rewarding!

The controls are unmatched, the game is 99% bug-free, the developers are active and listening, there's tons of secrets, an interesting story, perfect level design, just enough linearity to keep things in tact while leaving room for creative pathfinding, perfect difficulty scaling, interesting puzzles, one hell of a good soundtrack, literally the BEST visuals I've seen in a game ever, insane amounts of replayability, an active speedrunning community and just enough engine quirks to make speedrunning interesting.\n\nOne of my top 5 games of all time tbh.

reviewText: A great puzzle game that should not be compared with the Portal series. There is no similarity between the two besides jump pads. That's basically it. Anyways it's a great game that gets you thinking and rushing to survive and reach the goal!\n9/10

If you don't like puzzle and/or platform games, speedruns, and dying a lot, you will probably not like this game much, (you can still).

Deadcore isn't really a game for anyone, but it is really fun, and challenging: The obstacles and the level design are original, the platforming although would be much better if you could see yourself, because it sometimes can get a little frustrating dying a lot just because you don't have notion of where is your body, is great.
I don't blame much about the controls, they are okay, but I had some trouble dominating the dash (E), although something personal.
However, besides this, I loved the atmosphere: It is just beautiful, along with the soundtrack. The scenario for every level of the story, is just gorgeous. About the soundtrack most of the tunes fit perfectly with the game, if not, all of them.
The gameplay: It's pretty fun, once you get the hang of. For me the beginning was the worse, the learning curve is a little high. But after that, I absolutely fell in love with the game.
I completed the story in about 3h 15min (first playthough, lots of fails, not speedrunning, but also not that slow). However, keep in mind that the story has a lot of replayability (collecting some logs, etc.. or just getting a better time), and also you have a SpeedRun mode, which adds new maps, and more hours of entertainment.

Absolutely recommend this game.

reviewText: Would respawn again.
It's a 3 Dimensional Super Meat Boy. 9/10 would furiously yell at my computer and frighten my landlord again.

A platformer for the twitch-shooters, DeadCore features perfect jump controls and levels that are just frustrating enough that you'll keep retrying one jump for 20 minutes. It also features a special gun that can activate and deactive platforms, boost pads and other stuff. You can also unlock other moves, such as Dash, but I haven't prgressed that far.
PROS
Simple concept done very well.
Looks great.
Awesome music.
Doesn't get repetitive.
CONS
Can be frustrating sometimes (the tunnels when you first get Dash has me stuck for 20 minutes).
Sometimes you feel rushed, as though you aren't allowed to explore.
If you aren't a speedrunner, not much replay value.
THE VERDICT
Get it if you like plaformers, this is a great one!
I wish they've had more checkpoints since the difficulty between sections can vary hugely.

You will need to have good timing with your movements and the ability to multitask - flying through the air to land in a certain spot all while taking targets out. Challenging and enjoyed every second. Just get used to dying. A lot.

A platformer for the twitch-shooters, DeadCore features perfect jump controls and levels that are just frustrating enough that you'll keep retrying one jump for 20 minutes. It also features a special gun that can activate and deactive platforms, boost pads and other stuff. You can also unlock other moves, such as Dash, but I haven't prgressed that far.
PROS
Simple concept done very well.
Looks great.
Awesome music.
Doesn't get repetitive.
CONS
Can be frustrating sometimes (the tunnels when you first get Dash has me stuck for 20 minutes).
Sometimes you feel rushed, as though you aren't allowed to explore.
If you aren't a speedrunner, not much replay value.
THE VERDICT
Get it if you like plaformers, this is a great one!

reviewText:
I picked this game up on sale, expecting to spend maybe an hour jumping around on platforms killing some time..
4hours 10minutes later i ended up completing the game, in one sitting. (Very rare thing for me.)

It just completely blew me away. And i came back the next day, to start doing speedruns and finding the last sparks i was missing from the initital run.. I am now considering buying 3D glasses for my 3D monitor, to play my first ever 3D game.

Absolutely recommend !!!
Would respawn again.

It's a great game. I'm not a huge fan of platformers, but this one really took me for a few reasons:

1. The level design is some of the best I've ever seen. The early stages in particular are fantastic and the developers really use verticality to their advantage. This becomes less true towards the end (this might also be due to my lack of skill), but at the same time a form of backtracking is introduced that feels great, new, and allows a sence of freedom and accomplishment rather than the tedious slog that backtracking typically is.

2. The game teaches you how to play better. As someone who sucks ♥♥♥, this is a big deal for me. The game can be frustrating as it ratchets up the difficulty, but it also helps me improve and get better, quickly replacing any frustration with a feeling of accomplisment. This is huge.

3. General atmosphere/aesthetic. So at first I wasn't huge on the visuals. But the way everything fits together, from the logs to the crunchy sound effects to the art style to the music to the third dimension and first person rather than 2d is beautiful.

4. You can go fast. Yay.

Really recommend this game. Glad I picked it up.

3D fast paced platformer designed for speed running.  If you loved inMomentum or Cloudbuilt, you'll love this one too.  It gives more options for exporation, but slows the game down a bit compared to the other two.  The difficulty isn't quite as high as cloudbuilt's later stages, but its certainly not easy.  The players special abilities are innovative (especially the form of gravity manipulation used). I highly recommend.

Fast paced platforming game makes you feel like god when you succeed after failing a lot.

It reminds me a lot of some of the fast-paced segments of portal 2 except that is what the enitre game is like. Fast dying, respawns and reasonable check points help keep it un-frustrating. The music is nice and keeps the gameplay feeling smooth and exciting.

The levels are well designed and really push the game's wierd futuristic aesthetic. There are often multiple paths to choose from and some are a bit hidden. Indeed, the game rewards you with various collectables for finding some of these areas. As you progress you will enounter new mechanics, often in the form of upgrades. These mechanics usually have to be exectued while platforming somewhat precisly and quickly in order to complete the levels.

Enemies are usually moving laser walls (instant death), turrets(fires a shot that pushes you back), giant fans, etc. This is not a game that focuses on combat and shooting these enemies will either do nothing or just disable them for long enough to run past them. In short, enemies are more like obstacles than enemies of a traditional FPS.

There is no real storyline to speak of but there is hidden lore in the form of logs hidden about. The logs are short but entertaining enough to read.

This game seems like the sort of thing that could be very competitive and there are high score boards if you are into that thing.

Not sure how long the game is but I picked it up for under 4 USD and 2.6 hours throughly enjoyed so far, I already feel like I got my money's worth.

It's a Unity game, it looks like a Unity game with the choppy switch gun animations and the high resolution skybox that feels fresh out of a demonstration video, it feels like Unity in that hardware on the lower range will probably suffer. The backstory is a weak excuse to sprinkle collectibles around the levels (there's only twenty of them, they're text logs), and the plot is about as deep as the end sequence to Mass Effect 3. Speaking of three, that's about how many hours it takes to get the true ending from when you start the game for the first time.

This is the part where you imagine the stern face, the frown, and the shaking of head. This is then the part where you tell yourself, 'who cares! I'm going fast! Wheeee! There's times to beat, things to collect, one way to go, and that's up!'

As you should! Deadcore feels tight. The running, the jumping, the dashing, the rocket jumping, the platforming, racing along a knife's edge to some sick beats along the looming specter of some inexplicable tower, it's absolutely exhilarating. Once you get a feel for the game, once you learn how to get to the end of the level, well, that's where the racing starts. There's achievements, there's developer times to beat, your friends' times to beat, your own times- you will feel yourself getting better at the game and you might surprise yourself with how quickly you do.

A caveat, though- the game's kind of hard. It's very possible that Mr. Real Time Strategy On Weekends or Mr. Really Good At Last Hits isn't going to make it to the end. There's no losing condition, though, and with as 'short' as the game is, it makes it a very feasible goal. There's no grinding. There's no timewaster, no character progression. There's just you and your own skill.

Sure, maybe you can get the true ending in three hours, but there are completionist goals, and the brevity of the game keeps them refreshingly in reach. Again, it's not about putting the time in, it's about gaining skill, and pushing yourself like few games these days push you. And let me tell you, pushing yourself to make it to the top of the tower in under one hour... Mmmngh. Good feeling.

If you're a twitchy shootery kind of guy, or you dig fast paced platformers, and you think you'll enjoy finding the logs, music, and crushing time records, the game's definitely worth the ten bucks. If you're not, or not so sure of your skill, jump for it when it's on sale. It's popped up in a few game bundles already, so it shouldn't ever be too long between sales.

Now how can I review this game. It's a really good game that lets you practice speedrunning or even just enjoy. As you play through the levels you will notice that you can find upgrades to your gun" (don't know what to call it). Many levels (if not all levels) you can just play and have fun. I have seen that many people compare this game to portal and that is not really correct. It gives you a portal feeling
date: so if you liked portal you will definitely love this game. In my opinion this game is seriously underated and deserves a lot more plays.\n\nI'm giving this game a 9/10."

reviewText: An excellent example of the first person runner and jumper. Graphics are really good, music aswell, top class package. Not too many games like it, it's a bit similar to the Portal games. I would say it stands as a good rival to the Portal games. Good stuff.

Don't let the term Platformer-FPS scare you off, this game is somewhat similar to and just as fun as Portal 2. DeadCore's combination of tight controls and fast pace elevate it far above most other Platformer-FPS games. There may be a frustrating moment once in awhile, but once you conquer them you feel like a frikkin' ninja. The game is rarely cheap, so if you die, odds are you just didn't time something right or you messed up. Frequent checkpoints means that attempting a difficult section again is quick and painless. The art style never changes, but creative level design helps keep things interesting. New mechanics are introduced at a satisfying rate, and every tutorial consists of a few floating words and a simple puzzle to get you started. Difficulty scales nicely as you play further as well. Highly recommended! Hopefully this game will catch more attention soon.

reviewText:
To call this game beautiful would be selling it short. The environment is downright stunning. About half of my first playthrough was spent just staring at the scenery. Add into that a first-person platformer puzzle game, and you've got a great way to spend a day.

While speed is definitely very much a part of the game, it is more than worthwhile to explore a bit, as you might find alternate routes, helpful powerups, or even just a spectacular view. The different paths makes for great replayability, and a speedrun system pits you against yourself and others, so while it took me 4 hours to get through the story mode (the first time--3 hours the second) there is still a lot of game left in this.

If you enjoy a good-looking game, difficult puzzles, and fun platforming, then pick this up!

reviewText:
Deadcore is an impressive feat by Studio 5 Bits where you will essentially have to think, jump and aim in a very fast and fluid way. It is constant entertainment with no downtime and although some parts can take you longer to solve or execute properly, the feeling of accomplishment after that is something I've not experienced in ages!

The controls feel good provided you have a decent computer: it's a Unity game with lots of objects... playing this on my recent laptop (GTX 850M) didn't feel as nice as playing it on a real gaming desktop (GTX 670). There is a bit of randomness (especially in the robots AI) and a few glitches here and there but nothing really getting in the way of the experience. Oh and the aesthetics (visuals, sound design and music) are just dreamlike! Such a strong atsmophere for a game with almost no storytelling (actually there is a lore but it's entirely yours to find out!)

My first run took me about 4.5 hours. Might not seem that long but any additional level would probably be repetitive, boring or frustrating (also let's not forget this is a small development scale, not an AAA studio); I felt like it was the right size" and I've thouroughly enjoyed these 4 hours. The replayability is assured thanks to the speedrunning factor: you might not think you are the speedrunner type but try it
date: because flowing through complex levels with mastery will feel reaaally good!\n\nSo buy the game because it's really worth the bucks! And help out these new devs so they make more games like this in the future!"

reviewText:
Deadcore is a mesmerizing little game. This one totally slipped past my radar, and if it was not for the great Humble Bundles I would have taken even longer to experience it. To start out, this game is MADE for VR. When VR hits I totally hope we see more games like this because the idea of jumping around some tower in the sky and doing puzzles in an FPS environment is basically what a lot of people are going to go crazy over in the virtual realm.

As for the game: it has stellar art direction, though the game was obviously made on a budget. I consistently felt like I was actually involved and trying to escape or find whatever the story was pointing me too. I felt like I existed in the virtual realm, and even though I'm only on a 42 inch the game made me feel like I was in a virtual reality prison I had to escape. The devs deserve their win for that alone. They also encourage you to explore the tower and its offshoots with varied pickups throughout and sound files as well some interesting tidbits on the story that are vague but intriguing.

The level design is fairly masterful and you will always find yourself looking out to see what is around you and how to get there. The mechanics for jumping seem pretty straightforward to me and the momentum and actual controls felt good to me once I got ahold of how to use my DS4 in the game. I wasn't feeling too much lag at all.

It supports 4K now and you can use a controller with Input Mapper and Xpadder--I use a DS4--or whatever other combination you want to try. Keyboard and mouse controls are fine too. I did have to use custom resolution in Nvidia CP to get it into 4K, and then I added CP FXAA on top of that for a pretty stunning experience at 60FPS. It should also be noted it probably isn't the smoothest looking 60FPS game you have ever played but it does get the job done.

A remarkable game that I hope will someday find its way to more systems and definitely Virtual Reality.

reviewText: This game has a lot going for it.  However, the twitch" factor is very high.  To make a pun that current owners of the game will get … it’s “Sky High.”  It is my sincere hope that enough reviewers will echo my sentiments & that the developers will eventually enable a control panel & permit a “God Mode” so that talentless old folks like myself can at least observe the level design & artwork
date: which is quite good.\n\nI've unlocked a gravity ability
recommended: & I have given up on level 4.  I've seen You-Tube posts of nerds with superhuman gaming powers (& obviously way too much time on their hands) hurtling through the levels like a hot knife through butter
hoursPlayed:
yet I apparently do not have the patience to die as much as I have...anymore.

Don't get me wrong: it's a gorgeous game.  The movement is good.  The levels are well designed (despite their difficulty & oftentimes confusing mechanics.)  The colors are nice & the textures are good enough.  The game loads quickly & respawning is mercifully instantaneous.  It simply is too “twitchy” & it lacks a compelling story line to keep me intrigued.  The level I gave up on is particularly dark & chaotic.  Keeping track of which way is up became ridiculously impossible.

I would recommend this to someone young with very good hand eye coordination & a LOT of spare time on their hands.  I would NOT recommend this to anyone who has ever experienced a seizure.  Even some folks with no history of seizures might experience one while playing “DeadCore.”  I feel very fortunate to have purchased “DeadCore” for only $3.99 during a holiday sale; I can honestly say that the levels I DID get through were worth exactly that but not one penny more.

One last thing: folks who compare this game to “Portal” or “Portal 2” are vastly overstating this game.  There’s a gun.  It’s an FPS.  There’s apparently some sort of AI that’s taken over things & made a mess of the world.  Beyond that

reviewText:
I grew up and actively participated in the skill jump scene seen throughout various quake/halflife/unreal based games. I enjoyed the skill based challenge of these, they were rudimentary but there was something about the use of the game mechanics in such a unique way that captivated me. It never felt unfair, it was my own lack of skill. It didn't hurt there was an active community as well to be part of.

So along comes a game designed to capitalise on this as so few games have got FPS platforming right. Great looking and with some relatively tight mechanics.

However, where I rarely felt cheated before, past the half way mark deadcore constantly has sections of rote memorisation. There are long and un-checkpointed parts that force you to replay countless times to learn them. Even a half-decent FPS player would find it hard to impossible to judge many of the jumps on reaction. This is especially evident in the gravity sections, with no easy indication of orientation, its very easy to get lost before being summarily thrown into the abyss.

There are enemies whose only purpose seems to be to frustrate and foil jumping runs, you can only delay and cannot kill them. Your gun has limited ammo between checkpoints, that are again put further and further apart. This gun is required to activate switches yet can be depleted to stop aforementioned enemies, I cannot see how this was a sensible design choice.

Overall, an interesting concept with fantastic graphics, but layering on artificial difficulty with too many frustrating and confusing gameplay elements to remain as fun as it starts.

reviewText:
This is pretty much Dark Souls the fps platformer. I do not agree with people who bash this game due to difficulty, Yes its hard but thats why I have enjoyed it so much. The more difficult something is the better you feel after completing it. I don't want to just play easy Mario platformers all the time.

Every genre deserves a good hard challenges. There will always be multiplayer for challenges for normal FPSes and MOBAs. But games like platformers and RPGs need preset challenges due to the lack of multiplayer potential. Yes we need mario games and skyrim (compared to dark souls) for more causal players. and we also need games like Deadcore and Darksouls for more hardcore players. Deadcore is a great game if you are up to it, and I do not think that Deadcore should be critisized for its difficulty.

Also I think TB bashed this game for stability issues when this came out in early access, however I found no problems

reviewText:
Incredible.  The gameplay behond Deadcore is essentially a first person platform game which just so happens to have a gun to activate things. The game challanges you to climb a large mechanical tower made of levitating blocks higher and higher with checkpoints along the way. Sometimes it seems incredible how high one level can go.
The way you get around in Deadcore is by jumping platform to platform, using jump pads, stragetically whilst activating markings on some of the surrounding blocks, whilst dodging red lazers, autoturrets and floating security droids shaped as blocks or orbs which try to knock you off or into lazers in various ways. timing is important.

Throughout the early levels you get introduced to different abilities to climb this monstrous tower of jumping puzzles, turrets and lazers. A double jump at first, a boost which you can use twice before recharging, or hold down for a powerful boost forward and finally a kind of boost orb which when used properly can help propel you in the air after a double jump. However the gun you carry around is more like a tool and you can only fire 30 times, until you get a checkpoint where the gun refils with shots. This can be specially annoying when defending yourself from drones as you try to figure something out, only to reach where you wanted to go and find a marking to activate, with no point but to kill yourself and try again and learn through trial and error.
Just as you get used to the rhythm of shooting markings to activate jump pads at the exact moment, barely fit through lazers like the Japanese game show concept 'Hole in the Wall', then the game literally turns itself upside down with transparent markings on to of blocks which temporaliy affect your gravity in that purple highlighted area and that's where it gets a bit like Portal, getting completely misco-ordinated whilst climbing a tower upwards, suddenly realising what direction you are facing in mid air and quickly making a landing whilst some floating drones are trying to send a pulse wave so you can get incinerated by a nearby patch of red lazer.

Utterly brilliant and taxing, like my earlier reviewed 'A Story About My Uncle' but instead relies on perfectly timed jumps and a repetition and rhythm as you jump pad to pad and activate marking by marking. It's more like a physical training course and the reward of getting to a checkpoint where you can auto save your progress (and go back to the real world) is so satisfying, but it's so easy to fall into a trance doing each action at the right time and each move at the right measurement and you will swear a lot.

Minimal, mysterious, thrilling and very rewarding.

reviewText:
I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

One Hour Reviews #42 - DeadCore

I used to play Quake III back in the day, and I remember this one level in particular, Q3DM17 : The Longest Yard, which my friends loved to play.  It was different from most of the other levels in that the level took place out in space.  It had these floating platforms, and on the platforms you'd find these bouncypads that would bounce you from one platform to another.  Well, in theory anyway, unless something went wrong, which in my case it always did.  Like I'd get shot in the middle of the air and it would alter my trajectory and I'd miss the landing and fall into the void.   Everytime I'd die like this I'd lose a point (the game considered it suicide), and often I'd end the match with a negative score.

Today I discovered there's a whole game that plays just like this Quake 3 level. It turns out I'm not very good at playing this either.

Each level is laid out with a series of checkpoints.  When you miss a jump and fall to your death, you'll zot back to the last checkpoint you went through (or you can just press R).   Since there aren't other people to kill, instead the game scores you by keeping tabs on how long you take to get to the end of the level.  In fact, the big part of what reminds me of Quake III so much is the sense of speed as you move and jump through the level, as the game encourages you to speedrun.

The first level is setup to introduce you to the controls and objects you'll find in the environment.  It starts with the basics of moving and jumping around, then introduces you to objects that launch you around, and then things that start shooting at you.  You do end up with a gun, but rather than using it to shoot people, you shoot objects to either activate them (like doors) or deactivate them temporarily (like turrets).

It sounds pretty basic, but the game gets challenging pretty quick.  Soon you are having to do things like shoot at turrets in the air so they don't knock you off course as you are jumping.  Or you'll end up on giant spinning wheels trying to get your aim right so you can jump to a nearby platform.  Then the game throws this weird looking windmill thing at you that you have to shoot to get the blades to stop spinning so you can move past.

If you aren't a fan of platformers or are a very casual player, you may be turned off by the difficulty in landing jumps and timing things right.  Personally I found the game to be challenging, but also rewarding as I practiced and got better at navigating the level.  It took me 25 minutes to get through the first level.  The best time is under 48 seconds.  That leaves a lot of room for improvement.
