reviewText:
I've been on the fence about this game for the longest time, but after a while I finally cracked and got the game to see how it really played. I say now with the utmost certainty that this game met ALL of my expectations...

...In that it is just an obscenely terrible piece of software. At first thought after getting a hang of the basic controls I figured this could be a really cool game that I could enjoy for hours on end, but as its hardcore" difficulty began to show through I soon realized this game was wasting my time.

CONS:
- Poor cursor/blast firing; It honestly feels like the blasts aren't going where the cursor is aiming at. Sometimes I shoot a button or object point blank multiple times and it doesn't hit.
- Atrocious difficulty; it goes from "fair but challenging" to "hideously unfair" in record time.
- Fake difficulty; this is one of those games that tries to balance out the difficulty with allowing you to die as many times as you want.
-  Crappy abilities; the incredibly underwhelming Rocket Jump not only barely works half of the time
date: but also expends a third of your entire ammo
recommended: which cannot be replenished until you reach one of the sparse checkpoints
hoursPlayed: or die. Some parts of the game expect you to use this badly done gimmick with every single bit of ammo
voteText: and if you mess up just once
helpfulPercent: you won't have enough ammo to continue on and have to start over.\n- Confusing layouts; there are very frequent "Where do I go?" moments
votesHelpful: this is especially prominent in the gravity modifying segments
votesTotal: where you have a tough time just remembering which way you came.\n- Terrible precision placement maneuvers; I refer to all the instances where you have to "thread a needle" through the laser fields
votesFunny:
among other intolerable segments.
- Substantially less fun blind; this is a game that's only tolerable when you've already memorized what the levels are like. Otherwise you continually run into death traps that you could have in no way telegraphed.

PROS:
+ Fantastic Atmosphere; It's a huge void that I just itch to explore more and more of.
+ Outstanding Graphics; The Sci-fi Movie feel the game brings is a definite plus in my book.
+ Tight controls; despite the level layouts working against it a lot
commentsCount: the actual controls are pretty good.\n\nOverall an awful game at its core despite its pretty visuals. It's artificially challenging

column17: and I just don't care for it. I can understand a need for high difficulty
column18: but I've also stuck by the notion that I shouldn't have to practice a typical computer game with the same diligence required in neurosurgery."

reviewText: The game is locked internally at 50 fps. This means that even though your fps counter may show 60 (or whatever your maximum refreshrate allows), the game still actually renders only 50fps. The whole engine is locked at 50. If you play on a 60Hz screen, 10 frames will be repeated, creating a tremendously uncomfortable headache experience. The game is supposed to be fast paced. At the moment, you either play the game with the screen set to 50hz (or 100....if you are lucky) so that you can match the game framerate (you will have to deal with input lag at 50Hz).....or you don't.\n\nI chose the latter. It is supposed to be a fast paced game, it would be impossible (or just uncomfortable, at least for me) to play it at anything below 60fps. Despite many requests from the users, the developers never tried to do anything since release.

reviewText:
I do have to praise the asthetics of this game. And the ending was kind of cool.

Now for the negatives (disclaimer: my computer is a few years old and is not a gaming PC)...

If you played Portal, and thought this would be more of that sort of fun (as I did), you should know that this game is not like Portal. In Portal, the levels were basically designed for you to succeed once you figure out the puzzles. In this game, there are more demands on the user to get the right timing, the proper precise movement/alignment, and to react quickly to everything around you. Also, in Portal, you would probably die a few times as you go through it, but your respawn checkpoint was always close so you didn't lose much progress. Not so here; completing a section requires a series of complex maneuvers where you can easily screw up one of the steps. I died a total of 1,034 times my first time through this game. So, if you enjoy a trial and error process where you constantly die, you may enjoy this.

I also found the game glitchy. Maybe it's the age of my machine, but there were many times the game would lag momentarily (consistently at the same places), and it affected the simulation enough that I wouldn't be able to complete my maneuver. Also, it seemed like sometimes my second jump wouldn't respond (and more rarely, even my first jump wouldn't respond). Also, the target areas seem very small, so you have to be extremely precise. Additionally, your gun projectiles seem like they're infinite speed (i.e., you have to click on exactly what you're trying to hit, not try to lead the target so that the projectile actually impacts the target when it reaches it on your screen).

All that to say, my experience was more aggravating than enjoyable. I hope yours is better.

reviewText: I enjoy games with simple mechanics and an emphasis on speedrunning. But this game suffers from the same issues as Cloudbuilt in that it is far too complex. I only managed to get up to level 4 and I gave up half way through it because rather than offering lots of small simple levels, the levels are vast and complex and a nightmare to navigate. It is not easy (at least for me) to find which way to go as there are lots of paths. There are also far too many environmental death traps to navigate. By the time you get to level 4 it's no longer about being quick, but actually just getting through the game. Where Cloudbuilt fails because of its complex environments, extreme pace and many enemies, it at least manages to keep levels short and makes it clear that being fast is what's important. Deadcore, on the other hand, fails because it offers collectibles and long levels. The only thing that makes it remotely apparent that this is a speedrunning game is the timer on your weapon. I'm not sure if I misunderstood the game, but it seems to be that this is more of a deathtrap navigation puzzle" game than one in which you are under time pressure; at least in the first run. The core mechanics are very promising
date: as is the general aesthetic and design. But it suffers from complexity which makes it difficult to enjoy and recommend."

reviewText:
In a way. I actually like this game. Smooth graphics, amazing visuals, interesting storyline. However when I had gotten about half-way through the game. The gameplay started to drag on. Certain bits of levels you might see for the rest of the game repeated. I didn't want this to be a rage game. But that's what it turned out to be. This game was praised for its level design and at first I can say for the first 1hr to 1 hr and 30 mins it is on par. However the Dev's seemingly enough would take parts out of some of the levels and put them into others. For example you might have seen an obstacle in the first level repeated in almost every single other level.

I am almost sick of the same repeated parts in each level. One I picked up on, was one where their are 5 red laser panes, and at the end there is a boost to get you to a part of the level that would normally be unreachable. The farther you get in the game the more parts that you catch are repeated over and over again. The worst part the checkpoints get even farther apart. Which makes the repeated bits in levels even more noticable. By the third level I was absolutely sick of the gameplay its pacing was horrible, and just nonsense. The game however does try to add some new mechanics by about the 2 hr mark. However it falls flat on its face, as its mechanics do not match the levels overall pace.

Overall I would rate this game a 6/10.

Graphics: 8/10, The only major problem is how low resolution some of the textures are off in the distance, and how unrealistic they are. It is painstakingly obvious. The main menu suffers from this to.

Sound Design: 6/10 some of the sounds are so f*cking cool, but they repeat FAR too often for me to handle it.

Music: 6/10, The music is awesome. Futuristic, and overall it has a nice compostion however even 2.5 hrs into the game. You hear the songs loops. Not all the time like their is one song. But like seemingly the game likes to repeat certain songs more than others. Problem is the music gets a 6/10 because of how ♥♥♥♥ing stupid the level design is, makes the fast paced drum and bass music not match up with the level design. And the fact you repeat the same part of a level so often you want to turn the music volume off.

Level Design: 2/10. This brings the game down so much. Because it was what it had mostly relied on. It fell so far from expectations. It is annoying, repetitive, and sluggish. As I have said before it repeates itself alot, you might see entire parts of a level copy and pasted from other levels. Overall levels are put into this absolutely random mad copy and paste spree. Levels had gotten so damn annoying I got sick of it and did not want to play the game anymore. If the game was a rage game like you would have died a lot, I wouldn't have minded as much if the level design was overall good and was fast paced, not sluggish and annoying. Their was this one part in a level that had this super long segment that was literally copy and pasted from the previous level, like nothing was different.

Story: 8/10. Although the story is simple, in a way it is as equally complicated. The story, is extremely intresting, and just awesome.

Was this worth my ten dollars? For the 2 hr's of gameplay that were actually fun, I would say no. Imagine this game as the bad version of portal. And I tried to finish the game but I literally would see entire huge parts of a level copy and pasted. Like it was literally so bad that every level was pretty much the same. The only thing that would save this game would be if it had custom campaigns and workshop compatibility. Possibly, an in-game level editor. If you think about it most of the parts of levels are put together kind of like portal. Like mostly cube based, and things like that.

reviewText:
YUCK.  I HATE this game.  I hate first person platformers, and I especially hate heights!  If you happen to like jumping from floating box to floating box in a first person view and aren't troubled by vertigo, then you may enjoy it.  But I was constantly tensed up and gritting my teeth (NOT in a good way) and feeling like I was about to fall off my chair, and almost had a heart attack every time I missed my jumo and fell fown throughh the sky.

That being said, the visuals were beautiful, and if it were flat on the ground I would probably like it very much... but that would defeat the entire purpose of the game.  I want to make it clear that my dislike of this game has nothing to do with any flaws in it, it is entirely due to very bad vertigo on my part and a hatred of platform jumping in a first person perspective.

I got this game included in a Humble Bundle, I didn't select to buy it for itself.

reviewText:
Seems pretty cool - you race to the top of a mysterious tower by jumping from platform to platform using your reflexes and timing to get through various traps. The pace of which you jump from obstacle to obstacle got to the point where it could be pretty intense, but it was somewhat broken up but the laser tunnels that seemed to kill you no matter how dead in the center you were, or you'd get through them, and the last would melt you.

Then the gravity mod for your switch gun. Now it's a ♥♥♥♥ poor puzzle game with extremely disorienting camera flips each and every time you enter a purple field. The game's momentum simply stops when this happens. Now you must sit around at the same section wondering what the hell to do for several minutes at a stretch trying out several different things while the camera flips you around and ruins whatever plan you may have had. Then cubes and robot bugs fly after you and bounce you around to make it even more hilarious.

I can recommend this for the first big section before the gravity mod. But for me, it managed to stop the pacing of the game. I often asked What am I doing?" as I would try to figure out a plan and then lose my spot when the camera changed. If the camera changed slower
date: and was more clear as to where you just came from

8/10 for the parts up until the gravity mod

The people who complain about this game's difficulty miss the beauty of this game. This is by far one of the most spectacular looking games I have ever played. Three words come to mind when I look at the background: Godly, Heaven, Futuristic. It is still challenging but not impossible. It is not rare to die 5 times to get past one obstacle just like the original Mario games, but you will be able to get past them eventually. You may not even have to get through the obstacle the way the game wants you to. By that I mean, the way you solve the obstacle is very flexible. You can often go around, above, or behind your obstacle and there are even multiple paths to your ultimate destination. This game has no story, but it doesn't need one because the journey is the experience. I beat this game just now and it was an incredibly fun game.
Thanks to 5 Bits Games and BANDAI NAMCO for supporting Linux with this great game!

reviewText: This game is a little gem. Imagine something like Portal in a Tron-ish style ambience, suspended in the air. It's very challenging, even if it's not very long to beat. Definitely worth every penny!

FPS platforming is very hard to get right and I have to commend 5Bits for getting it right.

Also, I'd like to say this to the developers at 5Bits: You sick, sadistic sumbeetches!

It's like Mirror's Edge and TRON had a little baby girl that then grew up into a beautiful woman so mom and dad came over to you and used their steel toed boots to crush your skull for daring to even look at their little princess.  That's DeadCore.

DeadCore is brutally hard and if you have a fear of heights your ♥♥♥ will pucker so hard you'll stick to your chair like a suction cup.

If you're a casual gamer, don't bother.
If you can't deal with defeat, don't bother.
If you don't have the will to keep going when it looks like you're never going to get through a section of a game, don't bother.

The mechanics are simple, the game is well executed, and I never felt like I didn't know where I was going to land or where my 'feet' were.  But you have to understand that this game pulls no punches.  You either get in the ring to win or you go home.

I snagged Deadcore over the holiday sale purely due to the interesting art even though I was afraid I'd hate it due to its platforming nature (I can't time a jump for my life).  I've put about four hours into it and thus far it is exploding my mind in the best way possible.

The controls are intuitive, responsive and basically flawless.  The difficulty curve and level designs are astounding.  The game trains you (or me at least) at almost the exact rate to keep the game consistently difficult without ever feeling hopeless.  The puzzles and obstacles introduce new elements and re-use already introduced elements in new ways often enough that it never feels stale.

I'll be the first person to admit that I lose patience while playing games quicker than most people.  However, to my disbelief, I have yet to transform into a rage-fueled beast of pure hatred or really get upset or irritated at all while playing Deadcore.  I'm going to attribute this to the instant and painless respawn, reasonable checkpoints and entrancing nature of the games music and art.  I should mention that the original reason I bought the game, the interesting art, was exactly as enjoyable as I had hoped.

In summary I am really enjoying this game.  I hit play on a level and wake up 60-90 minutes (like I said I'm REALLY bad at timing jumps) later with my perception of time shattered, covered in sweat and filled with an honest sense of accomplishment.  My only critique is lack of controller/gamepad support, though I did read a post from the developer on the Steam forums which said they may add it in a later patch.  I don't mean to overhype Deadcore but all in all it's great game and I highly recommend it.
8/8 no bait mate

Tricky platforming, branching paths, tons of secrets! Feels very old-school in the best possible way. As an old-school FPS player (non-competitive), I never really had too much trouble getting through the levels; sure, some of the checkpoints were somewhat annoyingly spaced apart, but I rarely died more than a dozen times while trying to get through a difficult area (and that only happened a few times in the whole game). Most of the time, it was an utter joy zooming through the vast, contiguous spaces and navigating the difficult spatial challenges. It reminded me of the sense of flow you felt once you got good at a level in Super Meat Boy.\n\nOnly major issue so far is performance: running on my 2013 15 Macbook Pro (i7

reviewText: Prepare to be left disorientated and without direction.  You will be expected to perform bionic feats in a dark, unforgiving setting.  You will get sliced by countless lasers and not know what you did wrong.  You will be expected to execute a series of precise steps to get a higher point where you will have to immediately react to a new impending threat on your journey up and around a mammoth tower.  Thankfully there are many save checkpoints but not as often as you might wish.  Keep trying, refine your strategy and you will get better.  So far I haven't had to check for youtube walkthroughs to progress.  The music, sound effects, graphics and controls are all put together well.  I particularly like the soft gravity mechanics.  This one will leave you with sweaty palms. 8/10
Not too far through it yet, but very fun.  Those who enjoyed Mirror's Edge would probably like this one.  I get a similar thrill from it.

This is technically a competant platformer game, and the visuals are absolutely stunning. The game is capable of making you think outside the box a little to beat certain puzzles, which is really cool.

So why don't I recommend this game? Well, this may be a personal thing, but I felt that this game fell into the pitfall that a lot of these type of games do: Just because you have trouble on the last in a series of puzzles, you will need to replay the previous ones over and over and over and over and over and over and over again, to the point where, to me, it genuinely stopped being fun or interesting. It quickly went from a game of thinking to a game of repeating stuff I've done a dozen times just to get yet another shot at the one part that was actually giving me trouble.

I didn't hate this game, since when it played fair, it was genuinely very good. But it got far too frustrating for me since I simply hate having to repeat things I've already completed. I'd gladly play a sequel that doesn't do this.

This game will kick your ♥♥♥, it's best played in short bursts to avoid frustration until you get the level layout down and can attempt speedruns. However with this difficulty comes a very high skill ceiling, meaning that people who have a knack for it or put in the time to get good will get REALLY good, good enough to show off to friends and impress Youtube subscribers.
People have complained that this game only appeals to speedrunners and streamers and that it's a game designed to be watched rather than played, which I have to agree with, if you're not up to the challenge.
This game won't hold your hand, if you can't think fast enough and react quickly enough to solve puzzles on the fly while being knocked around by loathsome little death cubes and shot at by turrets, you won't be able to master this game. Maybe you'll be able to beat it through trial and error, but this is a game that rewards the player enormously for mastering it.

Playing this game goes something like this:
I can't do it!"
"This is impossible!"
"Ok I see how it's supposed to be done."
"@!#& I almost had it!"
"I did it!"

reviewText: Tired of having the game tell you where to go how to do it and when to press a button? DeadCore. There's exploration and a rough guide as to what to do and then you're left in a digital(?) world of this things going to kill you. So is that. And if you don't time this jump properly we're going to kill you some more.\nOne of the achievements is to make it all the way through the game without dying. I can't make it through one level or indeed one checkpoint without dying at least once.\nAll in all though I can't not reccomend the game. It's simplistically complicated. Ultimately its a platformer maze with the jumping and the landing on platforms. Then you've got your timed, not so much puzzle, puzzles. I've just entered a bit where I can now swap gravity around a bit. Because, you know, barely making jumps in one plane isn't hard enough. Get this game now or get it in a sale and you're going to have a good time.

Do you like challenging platformers?
Then this game is for you.

Do you like speedrunning?
Then this game is for you.

It's definitely worth risking a few bucks to check out.

I don't normally write reviews for games, but for this one, I felt it was necessary. Before I go into the negative parts of the game, let me start with the positives.

First off, the graphics of this game are absolutely stunning. I have not run across a game this beautifully detailed in a very long time, and the design and layout of the game is truly very beautiful. The game also incorporates two themes that I love, Tron and Portal. The game has an almost Portal like feel to it with the gun and the linear ascent, but not so much so that it feels like copying, and the world has an almost Tron-like design to it, so that's something that I greatly enjoy as well.

However, and this is a big however for me. The controls are very very very sensitive. The small platforms make maneuvering difficult, so I'll just say that first. You have to be ready with the spacebar and the respawn key while you are runing on those narrow platforms. Unfortunately, what makes matters worse is that the controls are hair-trigger sensitive. Press the right arrow key just slightly and you're suddenly plummetting into nothingness, and have to restart from the spawn point. Your jump key is also very powerful, launching you ten to fifteen feet at a time. While this can be a lot of fun, it is also a cause for a great amount of frustration. I also find that the camera is very sluggish compared to the controls, no matter how much I change the sensitivity of it, which makes it very hard to watch where I'm going.

All in all, while the game is fun and can get very immersive, the controls make it painfully difficult to play, and give me a severe amount of frustration. I do reccomend it, but just be warned that you might get stuck for a while on certain levels, so be wary.
How the heck do i use blast? alot of people have this issue and nothing comes on tutorial. all it says is to use mouse2, but that's also to aim. put up some tutorials on how to do one succsessfully
OMG...so pretty.  getting all areas of a level unlocked is a good guage of how you are progressing through them.  and then you do a speed run.  freaking awesome

Now, I haven't myself finished this game yet, although I can already see how awesome it is, so I am writing a review. First of all, the game has really awesome graphics, which is something I always look for. Then, the levels are very big and challenging, which is good because it makes the game last so much longer. Then, you can also compete with other people for the best times on courses, just to show off your skills. All in all, the game looks great! The only thing I don't like isn't even in the game, which is how the trailers don't really explain what this game is about. So, for those wondering: You are a person who is essentially trying to escape a tower by climbing to the top AND solve the mystery of why it's there in the first place. Anyway, this game is really cool, and is worth your ten bucks. (Be warned though: It gets REALLY hard, REALLY fast!)

Great looking platformer/FPS hybrid that is fun to play (although sometimes frustrating at first) and very challenging.

It isn't completely without problems. As it stands right now there are some minor issues with edge detection, and due to the perspective and lack of visual cues, a couple of obstacles feel harder than they should be since you can't easily judge the size of your hitbox.

Over time, you get a better sense of space and things become much easier. You also start to unlock new abilities which make the game feel faster, and it becomes really damn good fun. Recommended.

Only played through the first level, but love it already. Great game, a fast paced puzzle with shooting elements that looks amazing.\n\nRuns really well on my multi-monitor Linux desktop, albeit it's quite a beast of a machine, nevertheless the Linux support is quite good. Doesn't feel like a second class citizen, even though the game was made with unity3d, a development tool that doesn't actually run on Linux.

this is honestly one of the best game ever. you can easely get into it for hours and have tons of fun !

this is totally worth the money. steam sale or not for me its a must. simple, complex and mindblowing at the same time !

FPS platforming is very hard to get right and I have to commend 5Bits for getting it right.

Also, I'd like to say this to the developers at 5Bits: You sick, sadistic sumbeetches!

It's like Mirror's Edge and TRON had a little baby girl that then grew up into a beautiful woman so mom and dad came over to you and used their steel toed boots to crush your skull for daring to even look at their little princess.  That's DeadCore.

DeadCore is brutally hard and if you have a fear of heights your ♥♥♥ will pucker so hard you'll stick to your chair like a suction cup.

If you're a casual gamer, don't bother.
If you can't deal with defeat, don't bother.
If you don't have the will to keep going when it looks like you're never going to get through a section of a game, don't bother.

The mechanics are simple, the game is well executed, and I never felt like I didn't know where I was going to land or where my 'feet' were.  But you have to understand that this game pulls no punches.  You either get in the ring to win or you go home.

I snagged Deadcore over the holiday sale purely due to the interesting art even though I was afraid I'd hate it due to its platforming nature (I can't time a jump for my life).  I've put about four hours into it and thus far it is exploding my mind in the best way possible.

The controls are intuitive, responsive and basically flawless.  The difficulty curve and level designs are astounding.  The game trains you (or me at least) at almost the exact rate to keep the game consistently difficult without ever feeling hopeless.  The puzzles and obstacles introduce new elements and re-use already introduced elements in new ways often enough that it never feels stale.

I'll be the first person to admit that I lose patience while playing games quicker than most people.  However, to my disbelief, I have yet to transform into a rage-fueled beast of pure hatred or really get upset or irritated at all while playing Deadcore.  I'm going to attribute this to the instant and painless respawn, reasonable checkpoints and entrancing nature of the games music and art.  I should mention that the original reason I bought the game, the interesting art, was exactly as enjoyable as I had hoped.

In summary I am really enjoying this game.  I hit play on a level and wake up 60-90 minutes (like I said I'm REALLY bad at timing jumps) later with my perception of time shattered, covered in sweat and filled with an honest sense of accomplishment.  My only critique is lack of controller/gamepad support, though I did read a post from the developer on the Steam forums which said they may add it in a later patch.  I don't mean to overhype Deadcore but all in all it's great game and I highly recommend it.

Is this a dream, or is this a nightmare? Your skill decides.

This game is not for the faint of heart, be it with heights (especially if you have VR of some sort), or with precision-based FPS and platformer gaming. As many have stated, this will make you ragequit plenty of times; however, if you are sly, and on your toes, you can use the freeform restriction-less design to find a way around your problems. And who knows? You might stumble across a log, or enhancement, or a new path.

I've had dreams like this game before. Style and such, and even overall brutality. I wouldn't mind finding more Trial Towers like this game. This is fun. Then again, I'm also a bit of a masochist for these kinds of games. Definitely a trip.
The game's high point is its aesthetics and is very submersive in the beginning, pretty challenging too. Uh, get it it's good.

Want a challenging game? This is it. This game will make you spew profanities while trying to get past a really tough spot. Even though the game is at times immensely difficult, it doesn't feel unfair. You always know, that if you try hard and long enough, you'll make it.

Simply amazing from start to finish. I died 308 times and not one death stopped me from respawning and trying again. I didn't get every log, song, or orb because there are multiple paths and I was simply driven to go for he top instead of exploring.
An excellent first person platformer with tight controls and interesting levels. Special mention goes to the wonderful sound design!

A fantastically mind bending puzzler in the vein portal with it's use of non-euclidean physics and various simple but very well executed mechanics to build unique and challenging levels. And for those who like to speedrun it's got quite a few great tools to cater to it including leaderboards and a dedicated speedrun mode, for the collecters it's got a bunch of replayability by going back in and redoing levels and finding new paths that were previously inaccessable due to a lack of upgrades. I'd very much recommend this game to any of those who enjoyed the portal series and those who enjoy mind bending puzzlers in general.

helpfulPercent: and two: some parts are easy to understand
votesHelpful: but they require quick movement and on the spot thought process.  This is what made part of this game enjoyable.\n\nThe game also calls itself an exploration game.  I was highly confused about this until there was an option to go in two different directions.  I could literally choose which puzzle I wanted to perform
votesTotal: and the further you get

column16: and landed somewhere else entirely

reviewText: Tired of having the game tell you where to go how to do it and when to press a button? DeadCore. There's exploration and a rough guide as to what to do and then you're left in a digital(?) world of this things going to kill you. So is that. And if you don't time this jump properly we're going to kill you some more.\nOne of the achievements is to make it all the way through the game without dying. I can't make it through one level or indeed one checkpoint without dying at least once.\nAll in all though I can't not reccomend the game. It's simplistically complicated. Ultimately its a platformer maze with the jumping and the landing on platforms. Then you've got your timed, not so much puzzle, puzzles. I've just entered a bit where I can now swap gravity around a bit. Because, you know, barely making jumps in one plane isn't hard enough. Get this game now or get it in a sale and you're going to have a good time.

Excellent game if you like a challenge, because this game comes with one difficulty level: insanely hard. (Well, and a speedrun mode in case you thought dying hundreds of times per level wasn't enough.) With one part puzzle and nine parts reflexes, there's a lot of trial-and-error which makes it all the more rewarding when you manage to string together a perfect sequence of jumps; the game consequently demands an enormous amount of patience.

A fantastically mind bending puzzler in the vein portal with it's use of non-euclidean physics and various simple but very well executed mechanics to build unique and challenging levels. And for those who like to speedrun it's got quite a few great tools to cater to it including leaderboards and a dedicated speedrun mode, for the collecters it's got a bunch of replayability by going back in and redoing levels and finding new paths that were previously inaccessable due to a lack of upgrades. I'd very much recommend this game to any of those who enjoyed the portal series and those who enjoy mind bending puzzlers in general.

It isn't completely without problems. As it stands right now there are some minor issues with edge detection, and due to the perspective and lack of visual cues, a couple of obstacles feel harder than they should be since you can't easily judge the size of your hitbox.

Over time, you get a better sense of space and things become much easier. You also start to unlock new abilities which make the game feel faster, and it becomes really damn good fun. Recommended.

This game is fantastic. Everything about it is beautiful.
But none of those things make it so great; what makes it such a fun game to play is how it feels, and I can tell you first hand it feels amazing.
The flow and structure of the game is simple, yet beautiful; challenging, yet fun; and every second of it feels satisfying.
If i havent sold you yet, let me keep going.
If you think its linear, that its just a “walk through this, open door game
date: it all depends on what your approach is. You can walk a straight line and push through brick walls to find the end of the level
recommended: or take your time and find shortcuts to propel yourself forward. There are plenty of secrets to find

votesHelpful: if youre looking for a story

commentsCount: and they dont add much
column16: but they definitely dont take away from the core gameplay mechanics which you should be focusing on. But on the other hand
column17: some of said mechanics are actually explained through unlockable bits and pieces of text you can find.\nIf youre looking for your moneys worth
column18: then youre in luck. Apart from single-player campaign
column19: it also has a speedrunning mode

column21: too. Its a portal-esque mix of synths and electronic
column22: and it goes well with each level. Youll see a red thunderstorm of lasers and lightning
column23: and youll hear deep basses and dark grooves along with it. You come to a part where coordination is key
column25: and a drum and bass with a fast beat accompanies you as you race to the finish.\nIn terms of level design
column26: the game gives you plenty of mechanics to play with
column27: most of which are beneficial. However
column29: as youll be challenged along the way with a gravity field that isnt quite supposed to be there

column31: remember when I said "play with"? I essentially meant "Exploit". This game has taught me to think outside the box countless times. Basically
column32: if you think you can do it

column35: and ill see an unlockable that wasnt even there before. Sometimes even an entire different path to the end.\nIn any case
column36: this game is a beautiful mix of everything for casuals

Długo czekałem na taką grę od czasu pierwszego Portala. :D Jest to skrzyżowanie łamigłówki logicznej, prostej zręcznościówki oraz graficznego klona Trona. Szukanie sekretów dodaje tylko smaczku i zachęca do wielokrotnego pokonywania poziomów  - gorąco polecam! :)

I actually had a lot of fun with this. Very pretty game, has some great speedrun capabilites. The controls feel really tight and solid, and it has a lot of those utilites speedrun games need (instant restart, etc.). Definitely pick it up if you're into that sort of thing. Story fragments depend on finding secrets, so if that's not your jam, I'd suggest a brief wiki read after the game.

A fun, fast-paced puzzle/platformer. Combine your speed and skill to beat the obstacles along the way to the top of the tower (With some hidden collectibles around if you are the type for that).

It brings a few standard mechanics (double-jumps, dashing and jump-shots) to traverse a seemingly simple world where, by traversing jumps, boosters, gavity wells and more, you must reach the top of the tower.
Along the way, you will encounter a few enemies including turrets, deadly lasers and drones with repelling blasts to knock you off and fall to your death.

What initially seemed like quite a simple game turned complex relatively quickly and when combined with the attitude of being the faster 'runner', offers quite a difficult challenge. Adding to the general progression of the game, you can return to earlier stages to complete other sections after learning a new skill.

I would recommend to anybody really, it's a nice game to play despite getting slightly annoyed when you fail the same part 20 times in a row. Definitely look into this if you are a lover of speedruns.

If you love the lateral thinking/mind bending puzzle structure of Portal and the punishing difficulty of Dark Souls you'll find a home in Deadcore. Not only is the game stylish, well designed, excellently optimised with a fantastic soundtrack but it's the kind of game that has you constantly finding new techniques and ways of traversing the tower through trial and error. An impressive title that I can't recommend highly enough, it isn't for the casual gamer though, this game takes skill to get good at once it's revealed the core mechanics to you.

Brutal

Where do I start...Well here is what I will say. It is at first a bit frustrating, then it becomes challenging, then it turns into pure bliss and fun. When you start out the game, you are immersed into a beautiful world, a mix between portal, and a first person shooter (of sorts). It takes a few hours of practice and determination to get used to the way the world around you works, and the controls and when to time things.

At this point you hit the challenging stages. A few areas in this game will make you cringe, because it adds your abilities together to complete them. It becomes unrelenting at one point, but it slowly and eventually turns into fun. Once you complete a play through you find yourself wanting to go and return to the game to complete a 2nd, 3rd, 4th etc. playthrough. You essentially strive to become a better player at this game. This game was also made in unity3d which is a fantastic program for game design.

To sum it up, this game is a must buy for all players. It has a bit of RPG, Action, FPS elements to it. For the price they are asking, and for the length and beauty of the game it is worth every penny.
Tough but fair movement/timing-based puzzles... kinda like portal but without the portals.

As a fan of the Portal Franchise, this is a buy I'll never regret. The basic mechanics are simple, but the execution is what makes the difference, Of course there are some areas that can use work, where lasers phase the slightest bit through the floor and still kill you, and it is annoying. From what I've played of it, it doesn't hinder me from finding a solution (standing a foot to the right.) Sometimes the controls don't feel as exact as they should be, and it can be hard to navigate levels. Level design does get a bit unimaginative at points, but you do feel like you're progressing. Even though enemies are clearly designed to bother you or knock you off the level, there are times when that unexpected boost can help. Overall, I would say it is a solid game, worth the money, but in need of a bit of polishing.

There are a few parts in this game that will make you want to rip your computer in half. Or once where you go through another difficult and long section where you need to use alot of your ammo and then when you reach the end of that (most likely with little or no ammo) they still don't give you a f***ing checkpoint to refill, forcing you to restart and do the whole d**n thing over again.

reviewText:
First-person platformer with good controls and reactive movement.

There are no difficulty settings, and the twitch skill requirements in later levels might discourage older gamers. In many platformers you can compensate for slow reflexes with strategy and memorization. DeadCore is stricter than most and hard checks against your ability to press a key at an exact time in deciseconds are commonplace (dang laser walls...).

This is a solid game overall, and if you're confident in your abilities you can disregard this review. For everyone else this should be a maybe"."

Idk why so many people believe that this game is hard. That's partialy true: complexity proportianally raised with your skills. Anyway at first time I completed it in 4 hours when the best one score was nearly 35 min.

First of all minuses of the game:
- Music. I don't think that it's suitable and also it bit annoying.
- Game length. Just 4 hours, as I said.

Despite all this, I really love that game:
- Code is great. That's very rarely that some game with nice graphic don't freeze or lag on Linux
- Level design. Oh, goddamit! Those're the best levels I've ever seen! For example I restarted first level and completed it with feeling that I finished another one. Hard to describe it, just as perfect as can be.
- Graphics. It's good like at screenshots on steam page.
- Visual design. Pretty futuristic style makes nice atmosphere.

Around the end of the game, the levels became extremely hard, and the gravity shifting made my mind go wonky but the feeling of beating the challenge was amazing.
Go fast, Aim true, Enjoy this amazing game.

You're in a strange place. A cloud of dust is forming beneath you and a strange formation of blocks is floating above you. 2 places devided by a grid of lasers. You can't help but wonder, what's above?

Your goal is to reach the top of each stage, jumping across platforms, shooting at enemies and cursing at your screen.

This game is a blast to play. If you like challenging platformers then give this game a go. The sound design is excellent and the music kicks in at just the right times. Replay value is also great, each level has different paths to take and loads of hidden collectibles.

A fun little first person puzzle/action platformer with a futuristic setting. The puzzles/parcours are more dependant on reflexes and speed, rather than brainpower. Most levels have multiple ways to navigate them, each with their own challenges. It's got very crisp visuals and an ambient soundtrack.\nIt's got a story but it's not the main focus of the game, as all of it is given in text logs that you can unlock and read at your leisure in the main menu by finding secrets. Personally i think it's a good thing because that way the gameplay isn't interrupted.\nThe controls are a bit floaty"
date: your character builds quite a bit of momentum and the jumps feel kind of low-gravity ish but due to the level design that works in it's favour (although it takes a bit of getting used to if you played games like mirror's edge or portal)\nAll in all I think it's a pleasant little game. Not extremely memorable but fun nonetheless. If you love doing speed runs then this is certainly a game for you."

reviewText:
It's a really tightly designed FPS platformer with speedrunning influences.  It's no-nonsense - has a very minimalist presentation and never holds your head, but gives you exactly enough to master the mechanics as they get introduced.  Once you get comfortable with the movement, it feels great to zip around the levels.  There's tons of ways to optimize routes and the level design is intelligent with a lot of room for improvisation.

The aesthetics are nice - the palette is sort of TRON-esque with lots of neon blue and black, but they do an excellent job with the sense of height and scale.  I got sweaty palms more than once leaping around platforms with an infinite fall below.

The music turns out to be a great treat (if you enjoy electronica).  Fits the game but also happens to be good on its own merits.

Is there a story behind it at all or is this just about 3D platforming.\n\nIt's not a bad game. It looks nice. If you're into challanges (especially timed ones) with platforming, it's ok. I guess I just had the wrong approach and expectation when I got it.

reviewText: Amazing platformer. Kind of like Portal, but completely different....heh. You will die. You will die a lot. And then die some more. If you're an FPS player, I strongly suggest remapping the quick-respawn button to something other than R if you have a strong reload reflex.

I wouldn't reccomend this game to people who just want to enjoy the story and the gameplay. This game is for people who sweat off, get the fastest time on a level, try to beat their friends. DeadCore does a poor job in providing those 2 things, all it is, is a fast pace parcour game where all you do is jump.. And jump... And again. It gets repetetive after the first level for God's sake! Not to mention the graphics - there is almost nothing to render, why am I getting such a low frame-rate? I am having to play on Very Low because of this issue. And don't tell me I need to take up all of my processor's rower to render: A background, a bunch of cubes and a few moving textures, seriously... What kind of a computer do you need to run this sh*t at ULTRA 60FPS? Pathetic.

First off, this game is not like Portal. I know people like to compare it to that game, but Portal is about space-folding puzzles, holds your hand, doesn't really allow for imagination, and is great for casuals. This game's puzzles is about timing, accuracy, imagination, and speed. It's like a horseback archery obstacle course on drugs. For those who are a fan of the FPS speedrunning community, this game is a must buy. If you ever played the DeFRaG/CPM obstacle courses for quake 3 arena, this is your game. This game is a lot of fun.  It controls beautifully, and really ramps up the challenge to deliver a solid experience throughout.  The mechanics really come together to create scenarios where you have to be quick-minded and quick to react, with some sections simply requiring you to know what you're up against.  This creates an addicting flow to the game, like a first-person Super Mario Bros, but with a cool futuristic atmosphere.

Be warned however, this game does modify gravity in specific zones, and the transitions into and out of these zones can be disorienting, especially at the breakneck speed some sections require.  It will take some trial and error to figure out certain levels, but with how fun the levels and the mechanics are this is not a bad thing.

Also, after unlocking more abilities, visiting the first few levels allows you to collect more 'sparks', which enables even tougher sections to be unlocked.  These are very challenging but quite enjoyable, and gives it some immediate replayability.  With the unlocked abilities, simply exploring known sections and seeing what places in the level you can actually reach is also a fun exercise.

This is a pretty interesting little game that seemed to have popped up out of nowhere. It takes the the level design from Counter Strike surf maps and adds a platforming and shooting element with a clear emphasis on speedrunning. Whats really remarkable about its design is that it manages to do first person platforming justice. With open ended levels and a variety of failsafes after missing jumps, the player doesn't feel as if the first person angle is a liability. The shooting bits mix very well with the overall design of speed. And, while there isn't technically any combat, the targets and turrets act as a shooting gallery, turning a speedrunner into a speedshooter, keeping the player on their toes. In DeadCore, your eyes are just as important as your feet. A first for this emerging genre of speed runners"."

DeadCore is a very back and forth experience, and not just because you'll be making baby-step progress while relentlessly respawning at checkpoints that are just a bit too far away. Many of the features and mechanics in DeadCore are rather self-defeating: it's a platformer that relies on extreme awareness of environmental hazards and body positioning, but at the same time, is a first-person viewed game where you can't see your feet. It's a game that is so conscious of the impending need for repetitious retrying and respawning that it mapped a quickspawn button next to 'use,' but it spreads checkpoints thin for the sake of exploration. Movement is typical WASD, allowing for a straight vector of movement at 45° angles relative to the camera’s center, but will frequently require you to run a straight line while aiming at targets outside such a range.\n\nPoint is, DeadCore's biggest enemy is itself. But getting beyond that, if you can get used to the quirks and have a high tolerance for the inevitable friction, all while surviving a skill-based game that takes no prisoners, DeadCore offers an engrossing aesthetic that is well-implemented and even more well-polished; thankfully, the game seeks to capitalize on a more zen-like experience, rather than the standard (and played out) frantic cyber-savvy motif. A simple, quiet package, DeadCore may very well frustrate you, but it will reward you greater.

It can be disorienting at times with the perspective switching, as it will often times will reset your crosshair position.  Ultimately, it's worth a playthrough if you like platforming or Portal.

At it's core, this is a speed running game before it is a platformer. With sharp visuals, clean controls and a fitting sound track it's an easy game to lose time to trying to shave that short second, but beware, on your first playthrough be prepared to die ALOT.

The game relies on precision movement and quick reflexes and will punish you off you're off the mark. Look for checkpoints as you play through as they will save you a lot of time, and hence comes the risk when trying to cut corners; skip a checkpoint, and be punished if you screw up. This also plays into the routes, some are harder than others, some have fewer checkpoints, but if you plan to go for it, you can shave off minutes if you're successful. Due to this, it would be nice if they introduced a way to revert your checkpoint furthur, say, previous or 3 checkpoints before. It would make the overall game more casual friendly as some of these alternate routes, once you start on them, you're not going back... In this sense, the game pulls no punches. Shaving off minutes becomes really satisfying given how punishing trying to do so can be. Practice and memorise if you want to feel any real satisfaction, otherwise, this game is probably not for you.

The final thing I noticed is that you can't use a XBox 360 controller on this thing. Uninstalled promptly.

Deadcore is a simple game, largely involving getting from point A to point B through an elaborate floating maze using a fairly standard set of techniques i'm sure you've seen before in many other platforming games. However, it's also a beautiful looking game, a challenging game without being overly frustrating, and a game which controls amazingly; all of which makes the game an absolute joy to play. I'm currently on my second consecutive playthrough and greatly enjoying discovering alternate paths and trying to beat my previous times- highly recommended!

Several parts are impossible to one shot without knowing in advance what to do.

All in all a fun 3D plat former for those looking for a challenge. If you are looking for a casual experience be for warned and look elsewhere.

reviewText: Cool Platforming game

You're in a strange place. A cloud of dust is forming beneath you and a strange formation of blocks is floating above you. 2 places devided by a grid of lasers. You can't help but wonder, what's above?

Your goal is to reach the top of each stage, jumping across platforms, shooting at enemies and cursing at your screen.

This game is a blast to play. If you like challenging platformers then give this game a go. The sound design is excellent and the music kicks in at just the right times. Replay value is also great, each level has different paths to take and loads of hidden collectibles.

PROS:

+ Great level design
+ Excellent sound design
+ Addicting
+ Challenging
+ Speedrunning support ( there's a timer on your gun and there's a special speedrunning mode )

CONS:

- None found

A fun little first person puzzle/action platformer with a futuristic setting. The puzzles/parcours are more dependant on reflexes and speed, rather than brainpower. Most levels have multiple ways to navigate them, each with their own challenges. It's got very crisp visuals and an ambient soundtrack.\nIt's got a story but it's not the main focus of the game, as all of it is given in text logs that you can unlock and read at your leisure in the main menu by finding secrets. Personally i think it's a good thing because that way the gameplay isn't interrupted.\nThe controls are a bit floaty"
date: your character builds quite a bit of momentum and the jumps feel kind of low-gravity ish but due to the level design that works in it's favour (although it takes a bit of getting used to if you played games like mirror's edge or portal)\nAll in all I think it's a pleasant little game. Not extremely memorable but fun nonetheless. If you love doing speed runs then this is certainly a game for you."

reviewText:
It's a really tightly designed FPS platformer with speedrunning influences.  It's no-nonsense - has a very minimalist presentation and never holds your head, but gives you exactly enough to master the mechanics as they get introduced.  Once you get comfortable with the movement, it feels great to zip around the levels.  There's tons of ways to optimize routes and the level design is intelligent with a lot of room for improvisation.

The aesthetics are nice - the palette is sort of TRON-esque with lots of neon blue and black, but they do an excellent job with the sense of height and scale.  I got sweaty palms more than once leaping around platforms with an infinite fall below.

The music turns out to be a great treat (if you enjoy electronica).  Fits the game but also happens to be good on its own merits.

I love this game.

COLOR BLIND WARNING: Lots of red death areas. Took me sometime to get through the parts that started having them sadly they are a big part of the game. Game looks awsome but don't get if you can't see the color red.

This is a great platforming/parkour game for anyone who likes that sort of thing (think Mirror's Edge but with less emphasis on agile movement and more emphasis on equipment upgrades and route planning). Speedrunners will also enjoy this game as that is, essentially, the entire point.\n\nThose aside, this is another excellent first-person game that needs more attention. I highly recommend this game.

reviewText: Remind me of some platforming maps in valve fps. It's really nice. Air control ftw.

This may be the most challenging, punishing 3D platformer I've ever played. You not only have to be incredibly precise on your jumps, you also have to be at least a decent shooter. If you lack one of this qualities you will probably rage every five minutes.
It is very difficult but also incredibly rewarding. Checkpoints are located at a good distance of each other so you will never lose too much progress.
The tutorials are almost non-existant, and there were a few moments where I had to figure thing out via trial and error.
Other than that, I loved it. For someone who likes 3D shooter-puzzle-platformers like Portal or the recently greenlit Inverto, I found the pacing to be perfect. Instead of throwing you some boring tutorial levels where it's almost impossible to fail, you get right into the action, and the difficulty spikes right away.
The most difficult game i've ever played. I love it!\n

If you like cloud built or mirror's edge; this game is for you. If you don't like difficult platformers or first person games then this is not for you. It's a very specific game and it is not forgiving. It's like the dark souls of FPS platformers. I say that loosely though I'm only using that comparison to express how difficult it is.

Dead Core is not like Portal at all. This is not a puzzle game.

Watch some gameplay before you buy it!

I just finished Deadcore for the first time last night and I've already started a second playthrough to see if I can find all of the collectibles, get the second ending and earn some more achievements.  I'll probably mess with the speedrun mode for a bit as well.  So, my verdict?  Deadcore is a blast.  The game is a sci-fi styled puzzle/platformer/shooter where you're stuck in a sort of computer glitch/alternate dimension where you must scale a huge tower using quick reflexes and every ability in your arsenal.  If you mix Mirror's Edge, Portal, the movie Cube, Megaman and some other similarly themed games and movies, you will have Deadcore.  This is not a game for those looking to relax or have an easy go of things.  Your patience will be tested but there was certainly a sense of accomplishment whenever you'd complete a very difficult section and finally reach that elusive next checkpoint.

The meat of the gameplay sees you jumping from block to block/platform to platform while dodging moving laser fields, robotic foes hellbent on knocking you into the abyss and every other oddity you can imagine.  There are disorienting anti-gravity sections that will turn you on your head, jump pads, gravity tunnels that send you hurtling towards danger that you must avoid and much, much, much more.  You get a few abilities like a dash to help you out as well as the Switch Gun that does everything from activating objects in the enviroment that you need to use in order to progress to stopping your robo-foes dead in their tracks.  There is a story and it's told passably enough through numerous data logs that you can collect as you climb this digital Tower of Babel.  Speaking of collectibles, there's plenty to find.  In addition to the logs there are also music tracks, Switch Gun upgrades and Sparks (that open up new pathways of travel) to find.

Deadcore takes place in a pretty unusual setting that is brought to life thanks to some excellent graphics.  You'll truly feel the awe and scope of the situation you're in as you look up and see how far you literally have to climb to get to the next area.  Particle effects dazzle, threats are well-animated, dizzying gravity changes look awesome as the scenery flips every which way and the overall atmosphere is a slice of sci-fi goodness that looks simultaneously grand and opaque, all in the same breath.  It's not THE most beautiful game ever created as some of the enviroments can get a bit samey, but 90% of the time Deadcore is a pleasure to the eye.  The sound is pretty strong as well, if not quite as crystalline as the graphics are.  Robotic foes make c3po noises, your Switch Gun shots pack a fair punch and everything is perfunctory in terms of special audio FX.  Where the sound really shines is with the techno/industrial soundtrack that pumps adrenaline in the background; complimented by numerous dips into trip-hop ambience.

Even if Deadcore packed a simply average presentation it wouldn't matter much because in a game as challenging as this one, the controls are the most important aspect.  MOSTLY, they are competently well done and accurate enough for you to do the job but let's face it...you're going to DIE and die you will as you struggle with all of your might to pass the 5 main levels in story mode.  Jumping, dashing, shooting the Switch Gun and avoiding threats works most of the time and pulling off a series of daring saves and escapes is satisfying and breathtaking to chain together.  The real big BUT here is that sometimes things just don't work as they should.  Movement is a bit floaty and even if your leaps and dives are dead on the money, you are bound to go sliding off your perch.  The game has its own physics to master. Sometimes the game requires lining up perfectly between several moving lasers and these segments are rarely passable on the first attempt.  In addition to the float" controls
date: there are instances where your button presses won't register AT ALL.  My keyboard is new

reviewText: This game fiddles my ♥♥♥♥♥ I bought from Lidl and makes me wanna have a good ol' piddle my diddle ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)
Don't get this if you're looking for a casual puzzle platformer.\n\nCertainly do get this if you're looking for a challenge, this game is no joke.

A great game that, while possessing a relatively short single player campaign, offers a fantastic experience from beginning to end.  The game offers more post-game content in the form of time trials, composed of both areas from the story and additional maps of greater difficulty, but I find they don't offer the same magic that the main campaign offers.


Ultimately, the game is pretty short, but it accomplishes everything it wanted to in those hours, and ends before the game risks becoming tedious.  Very much worth your time.

Edit:  Don't ask me why, but the developers completely whiffed the projectile animation.  Your bullets look slow and inaccurate, but in actuality the gun shoots dead-accurate and instantaneously fast, meaning you should NEVER try compensate when aiming for a moving target.  Just aim for the target, and shoot.  It'll hit.  Ugh, wish someone told ME that while I made an ♥♥♥ of myself shooting at the fans.

While this game is hard, it is very rewarding. I am not a huge platformer / speedrunner but i consider myself slightly skilled in the genre. This game pushes you to the limit on every jump, but rewards you when you land it.  9/10 worth the pickup in the humble bundle.\n\non a side note, the audio and visuals are awesome. great job all around.

I love games like this, despite their occasionally infuriating nature.

Recommended to those who enjoy time trials and challenges such as Source engine surfing, bunny-hopping or rocket jumping. Though Deadcore doesn't offer the same mechanics exactly, it brings the same kind of feel and difficulty to a game that is more similar to Portal 2 (in style). Also some exploration is required for (full) completion as there are collectibles throughout the game and multiple paths to be found.

date: the difficulty is no extreme when compared to the Source challenges described above but obviously don't expect to do everything first try. For me

reviewText:
So, for everyone else complaining about difficulty, the learning curve becomes difficult after level 4 (because I understand that switching gravity is no joke), and the game can take around 4 hours and once you master it, in less than an hour; I love it, it's extremely well done, nice reactive movement control, there is plenty of room for shortcuts to skip puzzles once you get used to the environment, you can actually kind of fly, dash through the sky most likely, play with your momentum during mid air, which is more noticeable in the big final level.

This game is not just for fps speedrunners, you can take your time and that's what I did, I actually got 25 hours because I was afking, but completing the game with achievements (this game is my first, i'll tell you), takes around 15 - 20 hours top, also the achievements are not some grindy bullsh*t like in many other games, in fact they are challenging and you will get half of them during your first playthrough.

It's highly advisable to make speedrun maps AFTER de main story (getting all the songs is a plus but some during speedrun are just meh), also it's vital to learn how to use blast jump (however I  didn't know that there was a Blast upgrade until my second playthrough lol) it's as difficult as using speed boost jump" from super metroid
date: timing your blast to the floor and jumping at the same time it's a bit ticky.\n\nOh finally the soundtrack... Sweet soundtrack for the most part
hoursPlayed: I would recommend ascension (20 minute long song from level 5) at around minute 0:10:00
voteText: best part in the whole game in my opinion.\n\nI hope 5-Bits games make another indie title as good as this one."

reviewText: The real problem people have with Deadcore is the unwillingness to die a couple times on a one part. But through death the mechanics are learned, timing, speed, precision, etc etc. People say it's a really hard game, but I'm just a super casual gamer and yes, it is taking me time, but I'm getting through the game pretty fine and if I can do it, anyone can. This is coming from a person who less than a year ago struggled with aim accuracy on the first part of the Walking Dead when you had to shoot the sheriff turned zombie. This is a highly reccommended game that is visually stunning and simplistic. I got it on sale for about $3.50 and I'd say it's a pretty great deal

Would recommend but as a lot of people have already said it can sometimes feel frustrating.

Personally I would have preferred it without the enemies so I can just enjoy working my way around the environment, often I'll just get blasted off the platforms by enemies I couldn't see or could only see for a split second before they sent me flying.

Overall I do enjoy this game, would be very curious to see what the developer does next as this is (overall) a great game. Just be ready to repeat some sections 50+ times before you get it right!

If you like cloud built or mirror's edge; this game is for you. If you don't like difficult platformers or first person games then this is not for you. It's a very specific game and it is not forgiving. It's like the dark souls of FPS platformers. I say that loosely though I'm only using that comparison to express how difficult it is.

Dead Core is not like Portal at all. This is not a puzzle game.

Watch some gameplay before you buy it!

I bought it because it reminded of Portal. Thought it would be more puzzle solving oriented rather than focusing on time trials, but it turned out to be the latter. I didn't really understand the whole point behind it, except for gathering collectibles and power ups. What is the motivation? Does the story unfold later on? Is there a story behind it at all or is this just about 3D platforming.\n\nIt's not a bad game. It looks nice. If you're into challanges (especially timed ones) with platforming, it's ok. I guess I just had the wrong approach and expectation when I got it.

This is an absolutely must have game for anyone who likes platformers. Seriously, buy this game now or put it on your wishlist if you like platformers. It's rare that you find controls this fluid and responsive with level design this unique and open. The game is challenging but it's not frustrating due to the amount of checkpoints. Most of all though it's satisfying to play. The levels are designed to fully exploit the mechanics presented to you and allow you quite a bit of freedom in order to find the fastest possible route to the end. You'll hold your breathe, curl your toes, and let out a sigh when you finally overcome a challenge.

Holy ♥♥♥♥ this game is frusterating.

I love it.

Biggest pro: The level design allows players to take multiple paths, and rewards players for finding alternate solutions. For example, I was having trouble with a level that required the player to repeatadly dash through a series of gates and land on a jump pad. I beat it instead by using the jump pad to land on top of the gates and jump over all the obstacles. That exploit wasn't left in by accident; the devs clearly expected players to find this solution and didn't make any attempt to stop us from using it.

Biggest con: Checkpoint placement is always tricky to get right in a game like this. Too frequent and it feels like handholding. Too far apart, and the game turns from a test of skill into one of patience and your ability to learn the obstacles by rote. Deadcore definitely landed in the second court at plenty of points.

In addition, the greatest downfall to first person platforming is the inevitable lack of proprioception. There were some challenges that were very difficult to complete because playing a videogame means you lack peripheral vision and a sense of how much space you occupy.

Fun, but aggravating. I'm still on level 1 stage 4

Seeing how many people compare this game to portal let me explain why that isnt really possible and then I talk about my opinion on deadcore itself.

Deadcore is a game about reflexes/physical challenges in general. You know what you have to do, but good luck pulling it off. Sometimes you can improve your performance by figuring out an even faster way to nmove on and sometimes finding collectibles requires some thinking but you can play through without ever just standing there for half an hour wondering what to do next.  Portal on the other hand is figuring out the solution to a puzzle. Actually performing that solution in most cases isnt that hard.

Secondly there is nigh 0 story in Deadcore. That is not a bad thing, it isnt neccesary. There are hidden collectibles that give access to texts that will give you an idea of what the story is, but you have to find those first, so there is a good chance you go through the game without any story, also there is no voiceacting. This of course also means that there is no humor, but again that is not what this game is about or needs. Meanwhile Portal has its great and funny voiceactors that carry you through the game and you always know why you are where you are etc.

third the gun. yeah you use a physics doing gun in each game. In deadcore it is used to disable enemies and activate or deactive different mechanics, you dont always need it, there is a good chance you can get through a section without using your gun once. In Portal it basically is your main mechanic

So yeah that should explain why its an apple-pears comparison.

Now deadcore itself in my opinion was great fun. Some say it is to difficult and I can agree that it can get punishingly tough, but the last checkpoint usually wasnt far away and you get right back in the action. Id say a downside is falling off stuff since you are basically waiting to slam into death or going to the menu and clicking restart from checkpoint, neither of which are as fast as dying from anything else.

The abilitys all work and except for a rocket-jump like function all work very well, though sometimes precise landing can be a problem when for example your dash shoots you farther than you wanted. The rocket-jumpish ability btw almost never comes into use (in my playstyle, which means just trying to finish the level) so it isnt a problem.
Now the mechanics of the game world itself are mostly pretty good, but the gravitation changing combined with your camera moving and often the gravitation sections being the hardest to see where to go and what to do next can be a real pain.
Also the enemies could have been done better. I kind of feel like they are more of a nuisance than anything else. THere is a swarm of tiny enemies for example that slows you down and makes you less mobile and is therefor generally your death. This of course also means that once it has you escaping gets even harder. What is even worse is that these are most commonly found in the already hard enough gravitation segments. The other 2 enemy types are less annoying but all together I think this game could have done without them.
Oh and devs you will never read this but: PLEASE DEACTIVATE PAST CHECKPOINTS THAT NO SENSIBLE PERSON WOULD USE ANYMORE IN SOME PATCH! You can easyly lose everything in some sections of the game because instead of falling to your death you fall on top of a checkpoint hat is basically where you started half an hour ago and there is no way you can undo it and that is just rage inducing and a game killer.
Thankfully it isnt possible for this to happen often and probably you just have to have my luck for it to happen at all.

Now about speedrunning: yes, this game is used for speedrunners showing off with leaderboards etc. Is it hard to speedrun through? Is it good and fun to speedrun through? No idea, if there was an opposite of a speedrunner that'd be me. Though the game often offers paths that are faster but as a price more difficult. Now if you, like me, are not a speedrunner that isnt even an issue. How fast you complete the game means nothing if you dont want to shine on some leaderboard. Oh but dont excepect the game to be slow, until you reach a platform where nothing tries to kill you you have to be fast and precise or die.

All together great fun but not very long, by on sale if you like challenges

> First game 100%'d.
> Hidden bonus tracks delivered.

I have this game described as like portal, speed running the video game, and stupid hard and annoying.

I think that this game is more like a little of all three. It does play a lot like portal, with your FPS mechanics and how you jump and run as well as having small puzzles for you to solve. DeadCore is a first person platforming game. It has a futuristic setting and the whole game will throw you for a trip.

I don't think there is much in the way of story, just scattered words and logs across the game. Not really a big focus.

The main gameplay has you jumping and sprinting around. It starts our very simplistic but as they give you new mechanics things can start to become very challenging. I would highly recommend you don't play this game if you have some type of motion sickness as the gravity sections might be difficult to take. That said, the gameplay is very smooth, unique, and fun. Not many platform games give you this much freedom to move around with, and very rarely do you see first person platform games at all. The game has 6 or so levels, and took me about 3 and a half hours. The game also has collectibles you can find which would greatly add to the gametime, I personally didn't go for them. The game greatly encourages speedrunning, with leaderboards and even a speedrunning mode. Hell there's a clock on the Gun at all times.  I can see how the mechanics could be creatively used by speedrunners to get through levels quickly. I'm usually pretty competent at platformers and even I had a lot of trouble in some sections so I would say this game could be pretty difficult for more casual players. It could do with more checkpoints in some sections.

The overall look and feel of the game is something to be admired. While it can be a little monotone at times, the emptiness and beauty of the levels isn't lost on me, and some of the crazy mechanics will surprise you. I feel the gravity mechanic will be either greatly loved or hated, depending on your perspective, but it is something to appreciate that you don't get to see much in a first person game.

The game also includes a weapon and enemies but this is either meant to be underutilized or just meant to give you more things to do. Enemies are just there to be shot once, to stop them for a moment, while you continue platforming. I feel it's unecessary.


Pros
-Solid/Smooth Gameplay
-Very Pretty Aesthetics
-Creative Unique Mechanics
-Speedrunner Support
-Challenging
-Interesting Level Design
-Collectibles!

Cons
-Uninteresting/Lacking Story
-Might be too challenging or needs more checkpoints
-Somewhat short without looking for extras/speedrunning
-Droning Music
-Annoying Sound Effects (in some areas)
-Sometimes level design can be confusing
-Enemies and Weapon feel somewhat pointless

I liked DeadCore a lot. I feel that if it was a longer game there could be a lot more creative mechanics added instead of relying on the few ones the game has. It might not become your favorite game, but I would recommend everyone at least takes a look to appreciate what is being done here.

reviewText:
Rating: 9/10
Overview: First Person Platforming

The Good:

+ The story campaign features 5 levels split between checkpoints. Each level introduces a new mechanic adding a new layer to platforming. The levels feel like large obstacle courses that slowly ramp up in difficulty. Every level also  features multiple pathways encouraging multiple playthroughs.

+ Speedrun mode allows you replay the story campaign missions in addition to bonus levels that are unlocked by playing the story campaign to compete for the fastest times. You play these levels thinking how good you are only to watch  videos online and realize how little skill you actually have.

+ Great controls lead to great platforming. The platforming is less about precision and more about timing. When to dodge lasers, when to jump, when to avoid enemies etc. Every new section is like a puzzle, figuring how to reach the end, how to get the timing down just right etc, leads to a lot of satisfaction. You will die A LOT but that isn't a bad thing because every death means you learn something new. Once you die you instantaneously respawn at the checkpoint so you never have to wait. This may not seem important but when you die very frequently it becomes important to get back into the game as fast as possible.

+ Enemies are introduces in the later levels to add variety. You can temporarily stun them with you weapon or you can try to avoid them.

+ Techno soundtrack fits perfectly with the overall theme of the game


The Bad

-The game has a bug that doesn't seem to remember your settings every time you start the game. You have to go back into settings for the game to recognize it. Some levels had a few random bugs making it almost impossible to complete.
Restarting the level fixed these issues.

Conclusion

If you are the type of person to rage quit, this game may not be the best for you as it requires patience, timing, skill and a bit of luck. An enemy in the wrong place can make a good run turn ugly very quickly. If you are willing to  put up with that however, you may find yourself playing one of the best platformers on steam.
If you like to bunnyhopp in CS you will like this game too. :)
