Seeing how many people compare this game to portal let me explain why that isnt really possible and then I talk about my opinion on deadcore itself.

Deadcore is a game about reflexes/physical challenges in general. You know what you have to do, but good luck pulling it off. Sometimes you can improve your performance by figuring out an even faster way to nmove on and sometimes finding collectibles requires some thinking but you can play through without ever just standing there for half an hour wondering what to do next.  Portal on the other hand is figuring out the solution to a puzzle. Actually performing that solution in most cases isnt that hard.

Secondly there is nigh 0 story in Deadcore. That is not a bad thing, it isnt neccesary. There are hidden collectibles that give access to texts that will give you an idea of what the story is, but you have to find those first, so there is a good chance you go through the game without any story, also there is no voiceacting. This of course also means that there is no humor, but again that is not what this game is about or needs. Meanwhile Portal has its great and funny voiceactors that carry you through the game and you always know why you are where you are etc.

third the gun. yeah you use a physics doing gun in each game. In deadcore it is used to disable enemies and activate or deactive different mechanics, you dont always need it, there is a good chance you can get through a section without using your gun once. In Portal it basically is your main mechanic

So yeah that should explain why its an apple-pears comparison.

Now deadcore itself in my opinion was great fun. Some say it is to difficult and I can agree that it can get punishingly tough, but the last checkpoint usually wasnt far away and you get right back in the action. Id say a downside is falling off stuff since you are basically waiting to slam into death or going to the menu and clicking restart from checkpoint, neither of which are as fast as dying from anything else.

The abilitys all work and except for a rocket-jump like function all work very well, though sometimes precise landing can be a problem when for example your dash shoots you farther than you wanted. The rocket-jumpish ability btw almost never comes into use (in my playstyle, which means just trying to finish the level) so it isnt a problem.
Now the mechanics of the game world itself are mostly pretty good, but the gravitation changing combined with your camera moving and often the gravitation sections being the hardest to see where to go and what to do next can be a real pain.
Also the enemies could have been done better. I kind of feel like they are more of a nuisance than anything else. THere is a swarm of tiny enemies for example that slows you down and makes you less mobile and is therefor generally your death. This of course also means that once it has you escaping gets even harder. What is even worse is that these are most commonly found in the already hard enough gravitation segments. The other 2 enemy types are less annoying but all together I think this game could have done without them.
Oh and devs you will never read this but: PLEASE DEACTIVATE PAST CHECKPOINTS THAT NO SENSIBLE PERSON WOULD USE ANYMORE IN SOME PATCH! You can easyly lose everything in some sections of the game because instead of falling to your death you fall on top of a checkpoint hat is basically where you started half an hour ago and there is no way you can undo it and that is just rage inducing and a game killer.
Thankfully it isnt possible for this to happen often and probably you just have to have my luck for it to happen at all.

Now about speedrunning: yes, this game is used for speedrunners showing off with leaderboards etc. Is it hard to speedrun through? Is it good and fun to speedrun through? No idea, if there was an opposite of a speedrunner that'd be me. Though the game often offers paths that are faster but as a price more difficult. Now if you, like me, are not a speedrunner that isnt even an issue. How fast you complete the game means nothing if you dont want to shine on some leaderboard. Oh but dont excepect the game to be slow, until you reach a platform where nothing tries to kill you you have to be fast and precise or die.

All together great fun but not very long, by on sale if you like challenges

> Hidden bonus tracks delivered.

reviewText: Wow!!! so fun, love the speed run mode, music is amazing too.

This is a visually interesting and fast-paced FPS puzzler that relies on players fast reflexes and quick thinking.  It's challenge is the fact that it can deal with multiple dimensions as you travel up a strange tower riddled with some rather nightmarish obstacles.

I have to admit, this game is amusing and frustrating at the same time.  At the time of this review, I've only put a little bit of time into the game and what drives me is how each puzzle-obstacle presents a fresh, unique challenge.  I'm eager to see what's at the top of the tower, but I'm also coming off of The Talos Principle, so this will sit to the side for now.

It has great promise and if you're at all interested in fast-paced movement that relies on quick thinking to get you through, this game is an excellent test of your abilities.

6/10 The game is fun, but not too challenging game is a lovely way to spend 15-30 minutes of your time at a go.  There's nothing really fantastic about this game, however.  It's plain and simple, and that's part of its charm, I guess.  The fact that you can look up to see what's coming can be a little overwhelming, though.  This isn't something you're like to play again and again.

This would have been a great game,  but much of the level design is clunky and frustrating. Most of the platforms are spaced out at just the wrong length, so that you have to back up and try to precisely land on them (which may not sound like much, but really ruins the flow of the game), and there are some obstacles that are just plain not fun to try and get through, like those lines of squares with the lasers on the top and bottom that require perfect timing down to the milisecond or you have to restart. I stopped playing after trying about 50 times to get passed a badly designed obstacle to no avail. However, aside from those things, the core mechanics of the game feel really nice to control. I'd love to see a sequel in which more thought is put into the levels, and they're designed to flow well, where the challenge comes from staying focused and moving through the level with quick reaction time instead of nitpicky traps and obstacles that feel like it was the game's fault instead of yours for messing up.

GREAT game. a unique puzzle platformer that rivals that of games like portal. love the artstyle, the puzzle/platforming ingenuity, its anytthing but generic. although short, deadcore has great replay value with its multiple paths through each stage, collectibals and speedrun mode. using your abilities to find new ways past each puzzle is exciting. a non linear platforming adventure sure to keep you playing until its over. i myself beat it once, then immediatly beat it again. the movement is slick, responsive, and intuitive, the stages have alot of variety (no rehashing) its  one of its kind as far as im aware. on top of all the  soundtrack is great.

the only negatives i can say is its on the short side, i woulda liked a 12 hour game of this style with a bit more of a cohesive story, holding it together. deadocre is a quick 4-6 hours depending on your skill level. 1-2 after you learn the quickest paths.

i give deadcore a solid 8/10. 2 points of for lack of length or interesting story. tho if story is not an issue for you and you are just looking for some platforming fun, then its a must own 9/10 for platformer enthusiasts, only held back slightly by its length. :D

Wow, what a huge suprise. I bought this game during the Steam Summer Sale and thought it might be worth a few hours of fun, but I sure didn't expect it to be THAT good.

At first, DeadCore appears to borrow a lot from the Portal franchise: the silent protagonist in first person who has only one gun that is actually a sciencey contraption, the vast, dehumanized and very dangerous environments, the fact that you can fall from any distance without hurting yourself, no health bar, most of the sound effects are very similar, the clean techno-futuristic æsthetics... it even has got the cute little robots that casually try to kill you while doing silly voices.

But the comparison stops right there. Far from being a Portal knockoff, DeadCore seems rather like an homage, with its own distinctive personality and game mechanics. Here, the emphasis is really not on puzzles and reflection — most puzzles are solved at a glance and necessitate about mere seconds of thought; even if it gets mind-bending with the introduction of the G-Mod, it still doesn't really require you to think — but on pure skill. Mad skills, I would say.

This game seems like the embodiment of the popular gaming expression Git gud or git REKT". It really requires you to concentrate to a point you're not used to

Holy ♥♥♥♥ this game is frusterating.

I love it.

Biggest pro: The level design allows players to take multiple paths, and rewards players for finding alternate solutions. For example, I was having trouble with a level that required the player to repeatadly dash through a series of gates and land on a jump pad. I beat it instead by using the jump pad to land on top of the gates and jump over all the obstacles. That exploit wasn't left in by accident; the devs clearly expected players to find this solution and didn't make any attempt to stop us from using it.

Biggest con: Checkpoint placement is always tricky to get right in a game like this. Too frequent and it feels like handholding. Too far apart, and the game turns from a test of skill into one of patience and your ability to learn the obstacles by rote. Deadcore definitely landed in the second court at plenty of points.

In addition, the greatest downfall to first person platforming is the inevitable lack of proprioception. There were some challenges that were very difficult to complete because playing a videogame means you lack peripheral vision and a sense of how much space you occupy.

Fun, but aggravating. I'm still on level 1 stage 4
Have you ever wanted to play an FPS TrackMania? No no, be honest…
Don't get this if you're looking for a casual puzzle platformer.\n\nCertainly do get this if you're looking for a challenge, this game is no joke.

A great game that, while possessing a relatively short single player campaign, offers a fantastic experience from beginning to end.  The game offers more post-game content in the form of time trials, composed of both areas from the story and additional maps of greater difficulty, but I find they don't offer the same magic that the main campaign offers.


Ultimately, the game is pretty short, but it accomplishes everything it wanted to in those hours, and ends before the game risks becoming tedious.  Very much worth your time.

Edit:  Don't ask me why, but the developers completely whiffed the projectile animation.  Your bullets look slow and inaccurate, but in actuality the gun shoots dead-accurate and instantaneously fast, meaning you should NEVER try compensate when aiming for a moving target.  Just aim for the target, and shoot.  It'll hit.  Ugh, wish someone told ME that while I made an ♥♥♥ of myself shooting at the fans.

reviewerDisplayName: Tom Jones is on the loose
reviewText: Deadcore. With a name like that, you'd expect that this is some sort of futuristic game where everyone is trying to kill you because reasons. Well, close enough, I guess. Deadcore is a very unique experience, unlike some sort of futuristic game where everyone is trying to kill you because reasons. Some sort of futuristic game where everyone is trying to kill you because reasons is generic. VERY. GENERIC. This game is a First-Person Puzzle Platformer which focuses around a tool known as a SwitchGun, which, well, it switches things from on to off, or open to closed, or moving to stopped, etc. Shuts down turrets for a limited time, disables jump pad thingys for a limited time, opens doors, AND SO MUCH MORE! reviewText: While this game is hard, it is very rewarding. I am not a huge platformer / speedrunner but i consider myself slightly skilled in the genre. This game pushes you to the limit on every jump, but rewards you when you land it.  9/10 worth the pickup in the humble bundle.\n\non a side note, the audio and visuals are awesome. great job all around.

Do you enjoy doing the same thing over and over again 50,000 times?  They you'll love deadcore.

Ok, that's an exaggeration.  For $10, you actually can't beat the entertainment value.  Great graphics, a neat conecpt, and neatly implemented.  Very stable game, and very polished.  My only complaint is that the latter stages of the game turn into a 'success by 1000 tries' scenario.  You'll see the path to complete the puzzle in front of you, but due to a slight misstep or under calculation, you'll bite it and have to start from your last checkpoint.  This is particularly annoying when you have to dash through a narrow corridor upside down while spinning right side up as 5 lazers close in on you, or something similar to that.  It's neat when you get it, but the 999 times that you died before trying it cheapen the experience.  In the earlier levels, you zip around and you feel like youre accomplishing something using your skills.  In the latter levels, you feel like you eventually got lucky.

Overall, if you have $10 to spare, pick it up.  You'll enjoy it overall.  Just be prepared for a lot of trial and error as you progress.
Fun But Frustrating at the same time! 10/10!!

Now really, this game is superb in almost every way. The levels (only 5) are huge and the last ones will be pretty long and hard. In 5 hours you can beat the game, however there are some collectibles and the option to speedrun every level and beat people around the world.
Also, once you unlock one power you can use it forever, no matter if you start the game again. There is a secret ending, so replay value is correct.
Lastly, soundtrack is awesome, but I expected a bit more about the enemies. In the last level they were pretty annoying in some places, finally they could have added a final boss" similar to the last enemy you discover so the end would be just perfect and rewarding (I have to admit that the normal ending was cool enough).

9/10"

Deadcore is a fun yet difficult indie game that you should check out.
In Deadcore you have to climb a giant tower by jumping through a series of platforms and gravity defying obstacles. At first, the game seems easy since the first stages are basically jumping from platform to platform but the difficulty kicks in by the time the game introduces new mechanics to the player. One of these mechanics includes enemies that try to knock you off the platforms, instant death ray beams and an aura of purple that changes the laws of gravity. These mechanics add a challenge that most platformers can’t offer to the same degree. The only game I’ve play that is somewhat similar to this is portal, however, in portal the demanding parts were mostly trying to figure out how to navigate the testing chambers in a puzzle like way where in Deadcore the struggle was trying to maintain the right amount of speed while avoiding any death traps.

On the other hand, one of the few flaws of the game are certain areas that weren’t designed properly. For example, near the end of the game there were supposed to be a series of death pillars that moved towards you while you were stuck in a reverse gravity field but they started to glitch out so badly they started spawning at the end, sucking all the challenge away from the section. There was also a bit of a problem when it came to shooting, aside from the inclusion of iron sights (probably one of the most pointless reasons to have ADS) the precession of where you hit the targets were very demanding, especially when it came to the fan obstacles. Other than that, the game functions perfectly.

There is no real story in this game but it doesn’t need one, what matter when it comes to this game is being a fast paced platformer which it does excellently. Another aspect that I loved about this game was the design, this is by far one of the most visually impressive games I’ve played. I have an appreciation for games with abstract imagery being used as a background of the game so it’s no surprise that the visual style of the game blew my mind.

Overall, if you are looking for a game that’s fast paced, visually impressive, or challenging, then Deadcore is the game for you. It truly is one of the most underrated games out there and I would love to see it getting the recognition it deserves.

9/10

I just finished Deadcore for the first time last night and I've already started a second playthrough to see if I can find all of the collectibles, get the second ending and earn some more achievements.  I'll probably mess with the speedrun mode for a bit as well.  So, my verdict?  Deadcore is a blast.  The game is a sci-fi styled puzzle/platformer/shooter where you're stuck in a sort of computer glitch/alternate dimension where you must scale a huge tower using quick reflexes and every ability in your arsenal.  If you mix Mirror's Edge, Portal, the movie Cube, Megaman and some other similarly themed games and movies, you will have Deadcore.  This is not a game for those looking to relax or have an easy go of things.  Your patience will be tested but there was certainly a sense of accomplishment whenever you'd complete a very difficult section and finally reach that elusive next checkpoint.

The meat of the gameplay sees you jumping from block to block/platform to platform while dodging moving laser fields, robotic foes hellbent on knocking you into the abyss and every other oddity you can imagine.  There are disorienting anti-gravity sections that will turn you on your head, jump pads, gravity tunnels that send you hurtling towards danger that you must avoid and much, much, much more.  You get a few abilities like a dash to help you out as well as the Switch Gun that does everything from activating objects in the enviroment that you need to use in order to progress to stopping your robo-foes dead in their tracks.  There is a story and it's told passably enough through numerous data logs that you can collect as you climb this digital Tower of Babel.  Speaking of collectibles, there's plenty to find.  In addition to the logs there are also music tracks, Switch Gun upgrades and Sparks (that open up new pathways of travel) to find.

Deadcore takes place in a pretty unusual setting that is brought to life thanks to some excellent graphics.  You'll truly feel the awe and scope of the situation you're in as you look up and see how far you literally have to climb to get to the next area.  Particle effects dazzle, threats are well-animated, dizzying gravity changes look awesome as the scenery flips every which way and the overall atmosphere is a slice of sci-fi goodness that looks simultaneously grand and opaque, all in the same breath.  It's not THE most beautiful game ever created as some of the enviroments can get a bit samey, but 90% of the time Deadcore is a pleasure to the eye.  The sound is pretty strong as well, if not quite as crystalline as the graphics are.  Robotic foes make c3po noises, your Switch Gun shots pack a fair punch and everything is perfunctory in terms of special audio FX.  Where the sound really shines is with the techno/industrial soundtrack that pumps adrenaline in the background; complimented by numerous dips into trip-hop ambience.

Even if Deadcore packed a simply average presentation it wouldn't matter much because in a game as challenging as this one, the controls are the most important aspect.  MOSTLY, they are competently well done and accurate enough for you to do the job but let's face it...you're going to DIE and die you will as you struggle with all of your might to pass the 5 main levels in story mode.  Jumping, dashing, shooting the Switch Gun and avoiding threats works most of the time and pulling off a series of daring saves and escapes is satisfying and breathtaking to chain together.  The real big BUT here is that sometimes things just don't work as they should.  Movement is a bit floaty and even if your leaps and dives are dead on the money, you are bound to go sliding off your perch.  The game has its own physics to master. Sometimes the game requires lining up perfectly between several moving lasers and these segments are rarely passable on the first attempt.  In addition to the float" controls
date: there are instances where your button presses won't register AT ALL.  My keyboard is new
recommended: clean as a whistle and generally in top-notch condition

reviewText:
20 hours so far. Went through the game twice. Got all the shiny, floaty things. Played around with the physics quite a bit. Took lots of screenshots from start to finish. Game has a well-crafted atmosphere, fun music, and misunderstood polyhedrons that have been cursed by an evil deity with repulsive personal shield barrier devices. Never shall they know love... So tragic.

At $10, this game gives me a happy. Thanks five French dudes, I look forward to future releases.

P.S. Don't get this game if you hate problem solving. It's a problem solving game with emphasis on reflexes.

A very fun game. A good mix of parkour and platforming with an FPS type feeling to it. It's challenging without being straight out annoying, and the level designs allow you to sometimes find your own path instead of following the meant one. Also, since there's no downside with death besides going back a little ways, it allows to explore. And it's a gorgeous game.\nHowever, there are a few con'. Some of the level designs require precision, while the mechanics aren't meant to be precise, making deaths sometimes a little too common. Because of this, you often spend more time looking at the ground to see where you're going instead of the amazing looking world. And the difficulty curve can be a little much at times.\nHowever, it's still an enjoyable game.

It's a fun and interesting game, but you can't beat the 4th level, because the gravity keeps breaking on you, and not keeping you on the level of gravity you need to be on to beat the level or to even progress....
